webTitle: Bugs feel the heat in antique saunas

fields.headline: Bugs feel the heat in antique saunas
fields.trailText: Millions of bugs that are slowly eating up Britain's heritage are facing destruction - by sauna.      Pests such as the death watch beetle and the carpet mite, which greatly outnumber human visitors to English Heritage properties, are being treated in a slow-heating woodlined oven, in which trials have just started in the stable block of a Yorkshire     mansion.
fields.body:
Millions of bugs that are slowly eating up Britain's heritage are facing destruction - by sauna. Pests such as the death watch beetle and the carpet mite, which greatly outnumber human visitors to English Heritage properties, are being treated in a slow-heating woodlined oven, in which trials have just started in the stable block of a Yorkshire mansion.

Stuffed pheasants, a carriage and a Victorian nativity crib are being tested in the 16ft-long apparatus, with the fate of the bugs monitored by computer and x-rays. "Some last longer than others," says Amber Xavier Rowe, head of collections and conservation at English Heritage, as the dials at Brodsworth Hall, near Doncaster, nudge up beyond 40C [104F]. "But we've yet to find anything which can survive 55C [131F]."

The trials have big cost and environmental implications for the vast store of ancient fixtures and fittings in English Heritage's care - and the equally enormous trove of historical "junk" hoarded by families such as the Grant Daltons of Brodsworth. Ms Xavier Rowe said: "They never threw anything away, and even with a house the size of Brodsworth that meant there wasn't room to store everything properly."

Heirlooms such as a collapsible canvas boat and wax-sealed chests that housed papers from an endless Victorian court case - said to be one of the inspirations for the Jarndyce v Jarndyce legal epic in Dickens's Bleak House - were dumped in damp outhouses: perfect conditions for destructive pests. "Infestations will only start in damp or deteriorating material," said Barry Knight, senior conservation scientist with English Heritage, checking a beer-soaked 19th century barrel rack drilled with holes by appreciative beetles.

"They're a long and difficult job to tackle, and we've been looking for a simpler way of doing the job." The saunas, which will be installed in scores of other properties if the Brodsworth trials are successful, avoid the use of toxic insecticides, which are expensive and face increasingly strict regulations. Other methods have involved long and costly use of bulky freezers, which take at least five days to chill bugs to death, or fumigation in airtight bubbles. Both have been used on antiques in the main house at Brodsworth, but getting poisons deep into the heart of ancient wood has proved a hit-and-miss business.

Ms Xavier Rowe said: "More and more things keep coming out of the woodwork, as it were. The exciting and promising thing about this new method is that the slow heating gradually gets every part of the infested item up to a standard 55C, without damaging paint, wax, material or even the straw on the nativity scene." The sauna effect is also key, using moisture from the plywood to maintain humidity inside the sealed oven to prevent fragile objects from drying out.

Once treated, objects will be free from further attacks if stored in proper conditions, said Ms Xavier Rowe, though English Heritage is deploying sticky monitoring traps at Brodsworth in the trial, to watch for any escaped webbing clothes moths, golden spider beetles or silverfish.

fields.headline: Loyalists warned over violence
fields.standfirst:
Paramilitary groups' feud 'is going to end in death'

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, last night called for an RUC report into the spate of incidents in loyalist areas of Belfast.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, last night called for an RUC report into the spate of incidents in loyalist areas of Belfast.

His intervention came after Adam Ingram, the Northern Ireland security minister, met the RUC deputy chief constable, Colin Cramphorn, and senior security advisers to discuss the worsening situation of sectarian violence.

Mr Mandelson said: "This behaviour risks sparking escalating violence. I have asked the RUC for a further report on every aspect of yesterday's disturbing events. Police investigations continue into a range of incidents and I expect to receive their full assessment shortly. I will then decide what further action is required."

Mr Mandelson appealed to loyalist paramilitaries to end the violent attacks and the destruction of property. "It is very important that those with influence in the community use it to bring an end to this violence. I call on them to do so."

A man shot dead in a street attack in Dundalk, Co Louth, in the Irish Republic, was last night named by police. Nicholas O'Hare, 35, was shot by two gunmen on Saturday night in an incident thought to be linked to the shooting in the same area, last month, of a publican Stephen Connolly.

Mr O'Hare, who lived in Dundalk, was known to police and was suspected of being involved in a protection racket aimed at Mr Connolly's bar. He had served a jail term for arms possession, and was completing a suspended sentence for assaulting a police officer.

Speculation at the time of Mr Connolly's death indicated he had been shot for refusing to pay IR£500 (£386) a week protection money to a Dundalk gang.

Mr O'Hare's murder came as the government condemned violence in the Shankill Road area of Belfast at the weekend, in which 10 people were hurt in loyalist gun attacks.

More than a dozen houses were damaged during disturbances in the north and west of the city. Loyalist gunmen opened fire at the Rex bar on Shankill Road during a paramilitary parade on Saturday. Three people were injured in the shooting and seven more were hurt in shootings later on Saturday night and yesterday.

At least 16 shots were fired into a house on Ambleside street, which is the family home of the senior Progressive Unionist party politician Billy Hutchinson. The North Belfast assembly member said he feared the escalating feud between the Ulster Volunteer Force, the Ulster Freedom Fighters and the Loyalist Volunteer Force would have "serious consequences".

"It is going to end in death. These people attacked this home behind us. These are innocent people. They were out at their work. If they hadn't been at work at 1am they would have been shot dead."

The home of Gusty Spence, the former UVF commander in the Maze prison was also attacked. Mr Spence said "honest, decent people" were being caught in the violence and appealed to the paramilitaries not to take the country back to the "dark days of violence".

webTitle: Shayler returns as Yard investigates Gadafy claims

fields.headline: Shayler returns as Yard investigates Gadafy claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard wants to interview David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, about his allegation that British secret agents were involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard wants to interview David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, about his allegation that British secret agents were involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, it was disclosed yesterday.

The new twist in the long-running Shayler affair was revealed during a press conference at a Calais hotel on the eve of the prodigal spy's return to Britain after three years of what he calls political exile.

Commander Roger Pearce, director of intelligence and head of Scotland Yard's Special Branch said in a letter to John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer: "We would hope to interview your client about his allegations [about the Gadafy plot] after ... his return to the United Kingdom." The letter, dated August 14, adds that after consultations with the Crown Prosecution Service the Metropolitan police "is continuing to assess the allegations".

It is the first time Scotland Yard has indicated it is taking Mr Shayler's claims seriously. Mr Wadham, director of Liberty, the civil rights group, emphasised that Mr Shayler would be questioned by the police "as a witness, not a suspect".

Other officers from Special Branch are expected to arrest Mr Shayler at Dover this morning when he arrives on a ferry from Calais. They are expected to charge him with offences under the Official Secrets Act.

In a deal struck by Mr Wadham, the prosecution will not oppose bail and the three and a half months spent in a Paris jail pending the government's failed attempt to extradite him will be taken into account if he is convicted at a jury trial.

It is unclear whether charges laid against him will relate to Mr Shayler's allegation that MI6 officers were involved in a plot to kill Col Gadafy in 1996 or whether they will be confined to earlier, separate allegations, about MI5.

Mr Shayler has alleged that MI5 keeps files on prominent politicians, including Labour ministers, and that the bombings of the City of London in 1993 and the Israeli embassy in London the following year could have been avoided. He repeated his allegation yesterday that two MI6 officers - known as PT16B and PT16 - handed over £100,000 to one of the Libyan plotters in 1995. Asked yesterday if he was accusing two MI6 officers of conspiracy to murder, Mr Shayler replied: "Yes."

In defiant mood, Mr Shayler declared himself a patriot and said all he wanted to do was tell the truth. "I did what I did because I love my country; I'm not a traitor to it," he said.

Asked how he would feel when he saw the white cliffs of Dover he replied: "Very emotional."

"If I am convicted I will be a prisoner of conscience," he told the press conference where he was accompanied by his partner, Annie Machon - also a former MI5 officer.

Mr Shayler's prosecution, agreed by the former attorney general John Morris in 1998, will involve arguments over the disclosure of sensitive documents. Meanwhile, if Scotland Yard is really determined to pursue the Gadafy plot allegation the government could be subjected to further embarrassment. Robin Cook has described the allegation as "pure fantasy".

Mr Shayler said he intended to stand against Tony Blair in Sedgefield in the next general election as an independent.

webTitle: Last words from a lost son

fields.headline: Last words from a lost son
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Valentina Avelene never wanted her son to go into the navy. When Sergei got his call-up papers for compulsory military service last autumn, she begged him not to go, and tried to persuade him to hide at his grandmother's house for a few months to escape conscription.
fields.body:
Valentina Avelene never wanted her son to go into the navy. When Sergei got his call-up papers for compulsory military service last autumn, she begged him not to go, and tried to persuade him to hide at his grandmother's house for a few months to escape conscription.

But Sergei Vitchenko, 20, was determined to serve his country and refused to listen to his mother's entreaties. He was delighted when he was dispatched this year to take part in perhaps the most prestigious mission possible within the Russian navy, serving on the country's most sophisticated nuclear submarine cruiser, the Kursk.

The conscript Vitchenko was the lowest ranking member of the crew and struggled to be promoted to the position of junior cook. He took pride in his work and his letters home expressed enthusiasm for his new life.

As Mrs Avelene made her way yesterday to join the relatives' vigil within the closed military town of Vidyayevo - the headquarters of the Kursk command - she gripped two letters which could be the last words to come out of the doomed submarine - a letter from her son and another from the captain. Sergei's letter arrived a her home in a small country town in Lithuania nine days ago, the day the Kursk went down.

The letter, written on four sheets torn out from a child's lined exercise book, gives the impressions of a young submariner experiencing conditions on board a nuclear cruiser.

For almost a week after the vessel sank, Mrs Avelene was too worried to sleep or do anything except stare at the television, waiting for news. But yesterday, despite her profound exhaustion, the act of reading aloud her son's last words to her gave her momentary release from her anguish - prompting her first to smile and then to laugh. The worst is that she still thinks her son is alive.

"Dear Mama and Papa Thomas," Sergei began the letter to his mother and his stepfather. "I have received all your letters. I'm sorry I haven't written for such a long time. We were at sea but now we are sitting in the port, loading up rockets. "

Sergei went on to describe his pride at having earned his colours as a true submariner, after his first descent with the Kursk to the bottom of the sea.

Apologising for her son's poor handwriting, his grammatical errors and his liberal use of Russian slang, Mrs Avelene, 43, read on: "We were baptised as submariners - we were called to the command post where everybody drank a cup of sea water and kissed a greased ship's hammer - and then we got these papers and the commander shook everyone's hands. But after drinking the sea water, we all felt a bit sick."

He told his mother his next trip to sea would be over by the end of August, when he would return to land - and promised to take some pictures of the scenery for her, so she would get an idea of his surroundings. The letter, written on July 23 - just before the submarine embarked on its final journey - ends with another proud reference to his new job: "Bye, I love you. I miss you. Write to me, Seryozha (a cook)."

Carefully folded alongside this letter, Mrs Avelene has also preserved a letter she received from the submarine's captain, Gennady Lyachin, in May, informing her that her son was serving on the Kursk and praising his progress during his first few months on board.

This, too, is handwritten on cheap, rough brown paper. The absence of a typewriter, let alone a computer, is a chilling reminder of the low-tech world in which the captain of one of Russia's most advanced submarines was working.

"The command informs you that your son, sailor Vitchenko Sergei Alexandrovich, is currently serving in the Russian military navy on the nuclear missile submarine Kursk, one of the most modern, battle-capable vessels not only of Russia but of the whole world," the captain wrote.

Mrs Avelene proudly read on: "Your son, sailor Vitchenko, has started to grasp his job with interest and dedication. I am certain that for the rest of his life your son will bear the highly respected badge of a Russian submariner with pride, dignity, and honour."

The letter was signed: "With my best wishes, Commander of the of the nuclear submarine cruiser, Kursk, Captain G Lyachin."

Captain Lyachin is believed to have died almost instantly alongside all his senior officers on the Kursk when the vessel's control room exploded and water gushed into the submarine.

Mrs Avelene, a builder, arrived in the Arctic town of Murmansk on Saturday after colleagues at the construction firm where she works collected enough money to pay for her plane ticket. She had been unable to afford the fare, and the Russian military had offered no financial support.

She was waiting at the railway station yesterday for her daughter to arrive from St Petersburg; naval officials were then to take them to join the 208 other Kursk relatives gathered in Vidyayevo - among them 49 wives, seven fiancées, 42 mothers, 11 brothers, 16 sisters and 39 children.

In the face of all evidence to the contrary, Mrs Avelene was clinging to the hope that her son is still alive.

"I just want everything to be all right," she said. "I want my son back - whatever condition he is in. I know we can look after him and help him to get better.

"All my hope is now with the British rescuers and the Norwegians. I'm very happy that they have come to the rescue. They are working heart and soul to help our men. They feel for them far more than our own officials do."

Mixed in with this desperate, doomed expression of hope, was her deeply felt bitterness at the response of the Russian government and the military to the crisis.

She was horrified by the Kremlin's initial refusal of foreign assistance in the rescue operation. "I'd like to see [President Vladimir] Putin put in a boat and sent to the bottom of the sea - to experience what they went through," she said, suddenly overcome with anger.

"People get punished when they betray their country. But what if a country betrays its people?"

She was also dismayed by the lack of support from the military. Her family heard the news of the sinking on the radio late on Sunday evening; early on Monday they sent a telegram to the naval headquarters trying to establish if Sergei had been on board.

They received no answer. Mrs Avelene spent hours trying to get through to an emer gency hotline, but failed because the number was always engaged.

Finally she saw her son's name listed on television as one of the trapped men. No official had made any attempt to contact her.

Looking weary and dazed yesterday, Mrs Avelene insisted that she refused to abandon hope.

"I'm going out of my mind with worry; but I keep asking Seryozha to hold on and not give up until the end."

Sailor's letter

Dear Mama and Papa Thomas,

I have received all your letters. I'm sorry I haven't written for such a long time and that I am replying so late. We were at sea and now we are sitting in the port, loading up rockets. When we have done this we will go out to sea again and then we will return to Severomorsk for the military parade. Tomorrow I will try to send this letter.

Everything is fine with me; they finally accepted me to work in the ship's mess and so now I'm working as a cook and not in the cargo room.

I have just hurried to prepare lunch so now I've got an hour's free time. The cooks are a privileged class on the ship - we are allowed to wash every day and we get to sleep for 12 hours at night.

Tell me what the commander's letter said - what did he write to you about? I'm interested to know._

Congratulations on passing your driving test. So can you really drive a car now? To be honest, Mama, I can't imagine you at the driving seat. I can't wait for you to send me a picture of you behind the wheel.

When we arrive back at base, I will write to everyone. But I think we will be at sea until the end of August.

I have been awarded my submariner certificate. We were down at about 100 metres, but that's by no means the deepest our boat can go - even 480 metres is no problem. Later I'll try somehow to send this certificate home for you to keep as a souvenir.

We were baptised as submariners - we were called to the command post where everybody drank a cup of sea water and kissed a greased ship's hammer - and then we got these papers and the commander shook everyone's hands. But after drinking the sea water, we all felt a bit sick.

When we come back from the sea I will take some photos and then you can see where I have been serving.

Well, I have probably already begun to bore you all with my letter, so I'll stop.

Bye, I love you. I miss you. Write to me,

Seryozha (a cook)

Captain's letter

Dear Valentina Avelene,

The command informs you that your son, sailor Vitchenko Sergei Alexandrovich, is currently serving in the Russian military navy on the nuclear missile submarine Kursk, one of the most modern, battle-capable vessels not only of Russia but of the whole world.

Your son, sailor Vitchenko, has started to grasp his job as cargo-room mechanic specialist with interest and dedication. The crew is giving him all the necessary help. The command is certain that he will swiftly learn his duties. I am certain that for the rest of his life your son will bear the highly respected badge of a Russian submariner with pride, dignity, and honour.

The command assures you that it is doing everything it can to ensure that your son's time in military service passes as smoothly as possible.

With my best wishes,

Commander of the nuclear submarine cruiser, Kursk,

Captain G Lyachin

Mixed in with this desperate, doomed expression of hope, was her deeply felt bitterness at the response of the Russian government and the military to the crisis. She was horrified by the Kremlin's initial refusal of foreign assistance in the rescue operation. "I'd like to see [President Vladimir] Putin put in a boat and sent to the bottom of the sea - to experience what they went through," she said, suddenly overcome with anger. "People get punished when they betray their country. But what if a country betrays its people?" She was also dismayed by the lack of support from the military. Her family heard the news of the sinking on the radio late on Sunday evening; early on Monday they sent a telegram to the naval headquarters trying to establish if Sergei had been on board. They received no answer. Mrs Avelene spent hours trying to get through to an emer gency hotline, but failed because the number was always engaged. Finally she saw her son's name listed on television as one of the trapped men. No official had made any attempt to contact her. Looking weary and dazed yesterday, Mrs Avelene insisted that she refused to abandon hope. "I'm going out of my mind with worry; but I keep asking Seryozha to hold on and not give up until the end." Sailor's letter Dear Mama and Papa Thomas, I have received all your letters. I'm sorry I haven't written for such a long time and that I am replying so late. We were at sea and now we are sitting in the port, loading up rockets. When we have done this we will go out to sea again and then we will return to Severomorsk for the military parade. Tomorrow I will try to send this letter. Everything is fine with me; they finally accepted me to work in the ship's mess and so now I'm working as a cook and not in the cargo room. I have just hurried to prepare lunch so now I've got an hour's free time. The cooks are a privileged class on the ship - we are allowed to wash every day and we get to sleep for 12 hours at night. Tell me what the commander's letter said - what did he write to you about? I'm interested to know._ Congratulations on passing your driving test. So can you really drive a car now? To be honest, Mama, I can't imagine you at the driving seat. I can't wait for you to send me a picture of you behind the wheel. When we arrive back at base, I will write to everyone. But I think we will be at sea until the end of August. I have been awarded my submariner certificate. We were down at about 100 metres, but that's by no means the deepest our boat can go - even 480 metres is no problem. Later I'll try somehow to send this certificate home for you to keep as a souvenir. We were baptised as submariners - we were called to the command post where everybody drank a cup of sea water and kissed a greased ship's hammer - and then we got these papers and the commander shook everyone's hands. But after drinking the sea water, we all felt a bit sick. When we come back from the sea I will take some photos and then you can see where I have been serving. Well, I have probably already begun to bore you all with my letter, so I'll stop. Bye, I love you. I miss you. Write to me, Seryozha (a cook) Captain's letter Dear Valentina Avelene, The command informs you that your son, sailor Vitchenko Sergei Alexandrovich, is currently serving in the Russian military navy on the nuclear missile submarine Kursk, one of the most modern, battle-capable vessels not only of Russia but of the whole world. Your son, sailor Vitchenko, has started to grasp his job as cargo-room mechanic specialist with interest and dedication. The crew is giving him all the necessary help. The command is certain that he will swiftly learn his duties. I am certain that for the rest of his life your son will bear the highly respected badge of a Russian submariner with pride, dignity, and honour. The command assures you that it is doing everything it can to ensure that your son's time in military service passes as smoothly as possible. With my best wishes, Commander of the nuclear submarine cruiser, Kursk, Captain G Lyachin

webTitle: Brain death debate may deter organ donors

fields.headline: Brain death debate may deter organ donors
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Uncertainty caused by a debate over the possibility "brain dead" patients can feel pain could lead to fewer organs being available for life-saving transplants, the Department of Health warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Uncertainty caused by a debate over the possibility "brain dead" patients can feel pain could lead to fewer organs being available for life-saving transplants, the Department of Health warned yesterday.

An editorial in the journal of the Royal College of Anaesthetists called for anaesthetics to be given during any operations to remove the heart, lung, liver or pancreas of such patients, who would have been kept alive by a ventilator. It said that increased blood pressure and heart rate in the patient "could be considered to represent an organism in distress".

It is feared that controversy surrounding the issue could make the shortage of organ donors even more acute. The number of patients in urgent need of transplants outnumbers potential donors by 20 to 1.

A department spokeswoman said yesterday: "Over 1m people worldwide have benefited from organ transplantation. It would be a tragedy if misunderstanding about current clinical practice led to uncertainty among the families of potential organ donors and to a decrease of available organs for life saving procedures."

She added: "The certification of death while on life support following brain-stem testing leaves us in no doubt that a patient is clinically dead. The use of some anaesthetic agents to overcome remaining spinal reflexes in dead people is common practice."

Unease does exist within the medical profession, however. Philip Keep, a consultant anaesthetist at the Norfolk and Norwich hospital, said yesterday that he would not agree to donate his organs until it was clarified whether a person in such a state was or was not alive and could feel pain.

He told Radio 5 Live Breakfast that he would only carry an organ donor card if anaesthetic were to be routinely given to all donors diagnosed as brain dead, and predicted that such a step would bring forward more donors.

He said: "If I knew that somebody was going to give me an anaesthetic before my donor organs were removed, I would carry a donor card and I think a lot of other people who have got these doubts would carry a donor card as well."

He said there was public confusion about the term "brain dead" and the fact that organs such as the lungs, liver and heart cannot be removed if a patient's heart has stopped.

webTitle: Selection is reason for success, says professor

fields.headline: Selection is reason for success, says professor
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: League tables and some results may point in favour of single-sex education but they are only half the story, according to Alan Smithers, professor of education at Liverpool University.
fields.body:
League tables and some results may point in favour of single-sex education but they are only half the story, according to Alan Smithers, professor of education at Liverpool University.

Of the 25 top-performing schools in the Guardian's survey of A-level results published last week, of which all but three were selective, 19 were single-sex schools.

Research by Graham Able, headmaster of Dul wich College, in south London, has found that boys do on average 6% better in single-sex than in mixed schools.

At Hasmonean high school, in Hendon, north London, one of the schools in the Guardian's top 50 comprehensives, the school is co-educational but the children are taught in single-sex classes - the arrangement that David Blunkett, the education secretary, is looking at.

At Shenfield high school, in Brentwood, Essex, which introduced single sex lessons in 1994, 64% of boys last year achieved 5 A-Cs at GCSE, up 26%. Girls' results improved by almost as much. The school teaches all lessons in single-sex classes from 11 to 14, and English, maths and science at GCSE level.

But Prof Smithers said single-sex classes in mixed-sex schools was pioneered when girls were underperforming in science. The system showed that while initially results improved, girls were worse off after a longer period.

"If there is a head teacher who is enthusiastic about it they may well be able to make something happen, particularly in the short term, but over a longer period I am not sure it would make much difference at all."

The apparent success of single-sex schools in league tables had much more to do with selection than being single-sex, he said. Single-sex comprehensive, grammar or independent schools did not do significantly better than mixed schools in their category.

fields.headline: FO pressure after Britons' jail 'torture'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office yesterday said it had "no reason to doubt" reports that two British policemen who face spying charges in Yugoslavia have been tortured and paraded before jeering crowds.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office yesterday said it had "no reason to doubt" reports that two British policemen who face spying charges in Yugoslavia have been tortured and paraded before jeering crowds.

The FO also indicated that Yugoslav officials in Belgrade may be asked today by the British government to explain the latest allegations.

According to reports from the Belgrade jail where the men are held in solitary confinement, the pair have complained of beatings and have feared for their lives. "I felt it was all over, that we were not going to get out alive," PC John Yore reportedly said.

Detective Sergeant Adrian Prangnell, 41, from Hampshire and PC Yore, 31, from Cambridge, were stopped by an armed border patrol three weeks ago, along with a Canadian construction worker, Shaun Going, 45, and his student nephew, Liam Hall, 19.

Mr Prangnell and Mr Yore are reported to have told diplomats that in the five days after their arrest they were subjected to psychological intimidation, punched and kicked, denied sleep and forced to stand for hours in front of walls with their arms extended.

All four were legitimately working in Kosovo at the time of their arrest on the Montenegro border.

Last night the FO said it was "very concerned" about the torture allegations - reported in the Mail on Sunday - but said they needed further investigation. A spokeswoman said: "We are trying to arrange meetings with Yugoslav officials to establish if these claims have any basis. We feel the best way to help these men is to apply diplomatic pressure.

"We believe [Yugoslav president, Slobodan] Milosevic sees these men as a good propaganda tool to encourage support for himself close to the elections. The timing of their capture is of great significance. He clearly wants some kind of official recognition of his government by the UN. We feel the most effective way of putting pressure on him is to deny him that while these men are held captive."

Mr Yore and Mr Prangnell were coming to the end of a year's detachment with the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, training local police recruits for the UN. Mr Going was working on a quarry project and had mining equipment including detonation caps in his vehicle. Mr Hall was on holiday.

The four took a scenic route to Kosovo in Mr Going's car after a weekend on the Adriatic coast. They were stopped close to the Montenegro-Kosovo border and were found to have the wrong travel permits. An army truck took them to Serb villages where allegedly locals and soldiers denounced them as spies. Psychological terror was used to try to force confessions, said Mr Yore.

The men also appeared on Serbian television which claimed they were terrorists trying to overthrow the president.

fields.headline: Rescuers battle to open hatch
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Norwegian divers were last night battling to open an escape hatch on the stricken Russian nuclear submarine as the rescue teams on the surface clashed about how to proceed.
fields.body:
Norwegian divers were last night battling to open an escape hatch on the stricken Russian nuclear submarine as the rescue teams on the surface clashed about how to proceed.

Russia's deputy prime minister, Ilya Klebanov, leading a commission of inquiry, said the hatch was so badly damaged it would have to be torn off.

He said a decision had been made to use a crane on the Norwegian rescue ship to pull it off. He said a British mini-submarine standing by would not be able to dock on to the Kursk due to the damage on its hull.

But a spokesman for the Norwegian armed forces said the divers did not believe the hatch was too damaged. He denied a television report that a man had been found in the airlock below the hatch.

The Kursk plunged to the bottom of the Barents Sea on August 12. All 118 aboard are believed to be dead.

There was confusion last night about whether air had been found behind the hatch. President Vladimir Putin, the butt of national criticism for his taciturn reaction to the tragedy, pledged yesterday that the rescue effort would continue to "the last moment". "With sorrow in our hearts and, I do not exaggerate, tears in our eyes, we are following all that is happening in the Barents Sea," he said.

webTitle: Longest dispute turns on £6.40 a week

fields.headline: Longest dispute turns on £6.40 a week
fields.standfirst: Women summon 'awkward and stubborn' streak in four-month strike for pay rise
fields.trailText: The conventional industrial wisdom, among employers and some trade unionists alike, used to be that women were more biddable workers and less militant than men.
fields.body:
The conventional industrial wisdom, among employers and some trade unionists alike, used to be that women were more biddable workers and less militant than men.

That caricature was often proved wrong, but in one recent dispute after another - from the 1997 British Airways cabin crew strikes to the Hillingdon and Critchley Labels lockouts - it has been women who have set the pace in challenging the new industrial balance of power.

The latest to bear out the trend is a small group of mainly women factory workers in Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, who have been on strike for 16 weeks in an attempt to improve their £160-a-week pay packets. Last week, they defied a threat of the sack unless they returned to work.

Standing on the picket line outside the Foframe picture frame factory - as all 11 remaining strikers do for their full 37 working week - Ann Oliphant said she thought "women can be more determined than men, more awkward and stubborn" when it came to tests of nerve.

Ms Oliphant, who has worked at the factory for 27 years and has got by only by doing cleaning jobs in the evening, said of the firm's owner and managing director, Benjamin Perl: "He always used tell us to claim benefits if we thought our pay was too low."

Fifteen out of 21 Foframe production workers walked out in support of a claim for a 50p increase to their hourly rate of £4.29, worth 12%, at the beginning of May after Mr Perl told their union, the GMB, that he could not afford to pay any rise because of low-cost foreign competition. The strike followed the loss of days off and other cash benefits.

Since then, Mr Perl has made three offers of between 2% and 3%, five strikers have left to take other jobs and the strike has become the country's longest running industrial dispute. The strikers now say they would be prepared to settle for 4% - or £6.40 a week.

Mr Perl, who last week called the conciliation service Acas in for the third time after issuing the sacking threats, said such increases would drive his factory out of business.

He rejects the GMB's calculation that his workers are paid 10p for making a picture frame which retails in Boots for £13.50. The real figure, he said, was 60p. Pay any more and he would not be able to compete with Chinese imports, he said. In fact, he insisted, he was going to have to close the factory in six to eight weeks anyway - something the strikers say he has been threatening to do for years.

Mr Perl said: "The GMB has got a political agenda - they are trying to break a small man. The workers can't dictate to the boss what to pay. I love workers, I don't lay them off, I put them in packaging. But they have been involved in secondary picketing, they have picketed Boots - they have even had ex-miners demonstrating outside my house."

The GMB rejects the accusations of political motivation and points to Mr Perl's longstanding friendship with and support for the local MP and former prime minister, John Major. Last month, Mr Major met the strikers - who describe him as having been "very diplomatic and understanding" - and wrote to Mr Perl afterwards to express his concern.

Outside the factory, the strikers tried to persuade a truck driver delivering supplies to turn back - Parcelforce and several other large firms have stopped deliveries, but their work is being done by smaller owner-drivers. The driver told the women: "I agree with your strike, but I've got my job to do." He called his boss on a mobile phone, smoked a rollup and then drove through, grimacing.

Doreen Smith, one of the strikers' two stewards, was meanwhile relieved that last week's sacking threat - allowed under new legislation after eight weeks - failed. "What Perl is doing is slow torture for the workforce - but he tried to break the backbone of the strike and it backfired," she said.

webTitle: DNA tests clear five of backpacker's murder

fields.headline: DNA tests clear five of backpacker's murder
fields.standfirst: Thai police face complaints of incompetence and brutality
fields.trailText: The investigation by Thai police into the rape and murder of the backpacker Kirsty Jones effectively collapsed last night when five foreigners suspected of involvement in her death were cleared by DNA tests.
fields.body:
The investigation by Thai police into the rape and murder of the backpacker Kirsty Jones effectively collapsed last night when five foreigners suspected of involvement in her death were cleared by DNA tests.

Detectives said they were still holding two Thai nationals. But they admitted that forensic tests had not yet linked them with the murder. Their investigation is back to square one, amid resounding accusations of incompetence.

All five, who include three Britons, gave DNA samples after the 23-year-old university student was found dead 11 days ago in a downstairs bedroom of the £1-a-night Aree guesthouse in Chiang Mai. The foreigners were all staying at the guesthouse at the time of the murder.

General Aram Chanpen, the region's police chief, said yesterday that tests had eliminated the guesthouse's British owner, Andy Gill, 32, and also Nathan Foley, 26, a dual British and Australian national who dined with Ms Jones on the night of her death.

Also cleared of the crime were Stephen Trigg, 27, from Lowestoft, Suffolk, along with Stuart Crichton, 28, an Australian, and Jacquel Wilfried from France.

The guesthouse's Thai manager, Surin Chanpranet, 47, and Thai tour guide Abraham Narong, 34, who took Ms Jones trekking days before her murder, were still "prime suspects", Gen Chanpen insisted. But DNA tests on the Thais had not proved a link with Ms Jones's death, he said. More tests were being carried out.

While the general was giving his press conference, the tour guide, Mr Narong, marched in and complained that four officers had taken him from his guesthouse and beaten him up. "I was dragged into their van, blindfolded and put face down on the floor," he said. "They were kicking me and standing on me, and told me to admit I was the murderer. Then they took me to a room - I think it was a hotel room - and they took off all my clothes. They made me lie on the floor and were standing on my chest."

He added: "I did not want to confess. I did not do it. Never in my life has anything like this happened to me."

Mr Narong said he believed he had been targeted because he was a member of the minority Karen hill tribe.

These latest accusations of police brutality follow earlier claims that the Thai police inquiry into the murder has been insensitive and shambolic. "The investigation has been a shambles," an official at the British embassy was quoted as saying in the Nation, Bangkok's newspaper.

Officers failed to seal off the murder scene and allowed a Thai TV crew into Ms Jones's room before the forensic experts had arrived. Ms Jones's parents, Sue and Glyn, from the Welsh village of Tredemon, near Brecon, were also appalled when a detective suggested their daughter had been accidentally strangled during consensual sex. The police later said the case was still being treated as murder.

According to unconfirmed reports, Thai police are now interviewing three new suspects, one of whom is a foreigner. They are also anxious to trace the driver of a motorised tuktuk rickshaw, who dropped Ms Jones off at the guesthouse after she left a night-time bazaar. He may have been the last person to see her alive.

Gen Chanpen said that two more Thai witnesses who had heard screams at 1am had come forward.

The police chief said he understood the frustration at the slow pace of the investigation but he insisted that everything possible was being done. He also promised that the accusations of brutality would be investigated fairly.

He added: "Along with all of Thailand, I feel very sorry about what happened. I am very upset."

Ms Jones, who had spent three months backpacking in Thailand on route to Australia, will be buried during a public funeral service this week, her father said. Preparations will be finalised when it is known whether or not the Cardiff coroner will want to hold his own investigation into the circumstances of her death.

Last night the guesthouse's owner, Mr Gill, was still in custody after being unable to raise the money to pay for his required deportation. He is being held in Chiang Mai prison after allegedly overstaying the time permitted on his visa by two years. Mr Crichton and the guesthouse manager, Mr Chanpranet, are also still in custody, on drugs charges.

The guesthouse's Thai manager, Surin Chanpranet, 47, and Thai tour guide Abraham Narong, 34, who took Ms Jones trekking days before her murder, were still "prime suspects", Gen Chanpen insisted. But DNA tests on the Thais had not proved a link with Ms Jones's death, he said. More tests were being carried out. While the general was giving his press conference, the tour guide, Mr Narong, marched in and complained that four officers had taken him from his guesthouse and beaten him up. "I was dragged into their van, blindfolded and put face down on the floor," he said. "They were kicking me and standing on me, and told me to admit I was the murderer. Then they took me to a room - I think it was a hotel room - and they took off all my clothes. They made me lie on the floor and were standing on my chest." He added: "I did not want to confess. I did not do it. Never in my life has anything like this happened to me." Mr Narong said he believed he had been targeted because he was a member of the minority Karen hill tribe. These latest accusations of police brutality follow earlier claims that the Thai police inquiry into the murder has been insensitive and shambolic. "The investigation has been a shambles," an official at the British embassy was quoted as saying in the Nation, Bangkok's newspaper. Officers failed to seal off the murder scene and allowed a Thai TV crew into Ms Jones's room before the forensic experts had arrived. Ms Jones's parents, Sue and Glyn, from the Welsh village of Tredemon, near Brecon, were also appalled when a detective suggested their daughter had been accidentally strangled during consensual sex. The police later said the case was still being treated as murder. According to unconfirmed reports, Thai police are now interviewing three new suspects, one of whom is a foreigner. They are also anxious to trace the driver of a motorised tuktuk rickshaw, who dropped Ms Jones off at the guesthouse after she left a night-time bazaar. He may have been the last person to see her alive. Gen Chanpen said that two more Thai witnesses who had heard screams at 1am had come forward. The police chief said he understood the frustration at the slow pace of the investigation but he insisted that everything possible was being done. He also promised that the accusations of brutality would be investigated fairly. He added: "Along with all of Thailand, I feel very sorry about what happened. I am very upset." Ms Jones, who had spent three months backpacking in Thailand on route to Australia, will be buried during a public funeral service this week, her father said. Preparations will be finalised when it is known whether or not the Cardiff coroner will want to hold his own investigation into the circumstances of her death. Last night the guesthouse's owner, Mr Gill, was still in custody after being unable to raise the money to pay for his required deportation. He is being held in Chiang Mai prison after allegedly overstaying the time permitted on his visa by two years. Mr Crichton and the guesthouse manager, Mr Chanpranet, are also still in custody, on drugs charges.

fields.headline: Tourist stabbed in hotel row
fields.trailText: A French tourist was in hospital last night after being stabbed during an argument over noise with fellow guests at a hotel opposite Windsor Castle in Berkshire.
fields.body:
A French tourist was in hospital last night after being stabbed during an argument over noise with fellow guests at a hotel opposite Windsor Castle in Berkshire.

A man aged 34 and a 16-year-old, both from Surrey, were arrested and were being questioned last night at Maidenhead police station in connection with the incident at the four-star Castle Hotel.

Police said that the Frenchman, aged 53, and on holiday from Strasbourg together with his wife and eight-year-old daughter, had left their room and gone into a neighbouring room just before 1.30am yesterday, where he became involved in an argument with the occupants. Sergeant Kevin Warner of Thames Valley police said: "The stabbing took place in another room, where the victim had gone to complain about the noise."

The man, who has not been named, was taken to Wexham Park hospital in nearby Slough with stab wounds in the chest, where he was operated on. His condition afterward was described as stable.

The hotel said it had found alternative accommodation for his wife and daughter.

The £220-a-night hotel is owned by Granada, and is directly opposite Windsor Castle. Last night the hotel's duty manager declined to comment beyond confirming that the incident had taken place.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Addiction help for footballers

Moves by the Arsenal captain, Tony Adams, to open a centre to treat footballers' addictions have been welcomed by the Football Association.

He hopes to open a 12-bed treatment centre complete with soccer pitch, pool and gym.

Adams, 33, who could be named as England's next captain this week, beat his addiction to alcohol four years ago.

Shakespeare play into orbit

The International Astronomical Union has named more of the moons of Uranus after characters from Shakespeare's play The Tempest.

Ariel and Miranda are joined by Prospero, the magician master of the island in the play, Setebos, who enslaves the sprite Ariel, and Stephano, the ship's butler - replacing the temporary designations S/1999 U3, U1 and U2. The names Caliban and Sycorax, provisionally given to two moons discovered in 1997, have been formally confirmed.

Talking cards for the blind

A range of talking greeting cards for the blind is launched today by Tesco.

They record a 20-second message, as an alternative to hard-to-come-by birthday or Christmas cards with messages in Braille.

Keeping the fizz

A way has been invented to improve the taste of drinks sold in plastic bottles.

Research, funded by Coca-Cola, found a molecule to make the plastic more impervious - letting less oxygen leak in and less carbon dioxide leak out, which alters the flavour and makes the fizz in the drink go flat.

£12m rollover

There were no winners of Saturday's £7.5m lottery jackpot, making Wednesday's draw a £12m rollover.

The winning numbers were 5, 22, 34, 38, 43, 46 and the bonus ball was 9. The Thunderball numbers were 9, 11, 13, 15, 18, and the Thunderball was 6.

webTitle: Analysis: can America develop a third major party?

fields.headline: No third way
fields.standfirst:
Ralph Nader, the consumer rights activist, is running for US president as a Green. He won't win - but he might put the squeeze on Al Gore

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Ralph Nader, the consumer rights activist, is running for US president as a Green. He won't win - but he might put the squeeze on Al Gore
fields.body:
Al Gore, now installed as Democratic candidate for the US presidency, has more to worry about than just George W Bush. There is also a potential threat from a third-party candidate. Not from the Reform party, founded by Ross Perot but now hopelessly split, with two rival factions claiming its candidacy, but from Ralph Nader, the veteran consumer crusader, running now on a green ticket.

Some analysts warn that Nader could do serious damage to Gore, especially by bleeding off votes he needs to take California.

Nader could have that kind of effect without coming anywhere near the success of Perot, who in 1992 took 19% of the popular vote - the largest share for any third-party candidate in the 20th century. Yet Perot failed even then to break the two-party mould, as he had hoped.

The last third force to do that was the Republican party. In the exceptional crisis of the 1850s over slavery, the existing parties collapsed, allowing Abraham Lincoln to take the presidency in 1860 with only 39% of the popular vote and no support at all in 10 of the 33 states which then existed.

After that, the system evolved precisely to make it hard for such disintegration to happen again. In the 20th century no third party - populist, progressive, socialist or communist - succeeded in mounting a serious challenge to the major parties.

Nader - articulate, experienced and above all honest - hopes to equal or even surpass Perot's performance eight years ago. But to have that kind of popular effect he would need to win a majority of the popular vote in a populous state, such as California, Texas or New York, or even a middle-size state, such as Illinois or Ohio. He would also have to do it in a close-fought election.

The American constitution stipulates that when the polls close on November 7, 540 members of an electoral college must meet to choose the president. This is usually a formality. But, as in any first-past-the-post election, if more than two candidates are contending, it is possible that no one will win more than half the vote. Only by custom and practice, not by law, do college members follow the popular vote in their states, since the whole idea of the electoral college was to modify the tyranny of majorities.

Were Bush and Gore to win states with a roughly equal number of college votes, third-party intervention could be decisive. If a third-party candidate were to win states which gave him or her 40 votes in the electoral college, with Bush and Gore winning 250 each, the college could not elect a new president.

In such a case, the House of Representatives would decide, with each Congress-person free to choose between the top two candidates in the college - in this case, Bush and Gore. That has only happened once - in 1824, when there were five major candidates - although the 1876 presidential election was finally decided only by a special federal commission.

Fringe third parties always run candidates for president, but only two have made any national impact. In 1948, Governor Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, running as an insurgent Democrat against Harry Truman, carried his own state plus Alabama, Louisiana and Mississippi. Though Truman narrowly won that election, Thurmond's intervention revealed the strength of white southern resistance to affirmative action on civil rights and helped slow the pace of racial integration during the 1950s.

Mindful of Thurmond's example, in 1968 Governor George Wallace of Alabama ran as an insurgent southern Democrat. He won the same states as Thurmond 20 years earlier and took 13% of the popular vote nationally. Wallace's support in southern cities was impressive, including more than a third of the vote in towns in Arkansas, Florida, North Carolina and Tennessee. Nixon just scraped into the White House, however. In 1972, Wallace did well in Democratic primaries in Maryland, Florida and Michigan, this last state revealing working-class support in the industrial north. He looked poised to surpass his 1968 performance until a madman shot him and ended his political career.

Wallace was a dangerous racist demagogue who articulated the hopes, fears and grievances of millions of white Americans, the working poor in every community and state who felt excluded from conventional politics. These "forgotten Americans", lacking secure employment, health care and opportunity, resent the fact that they do not share in the abundance of American life and hate paying taxes for welfare they do not receive. Wallace paved the way for those "Democrats for Reagan" who, in the 1980s, finally brought to an end the Democratic coalition that had elected Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman, John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson.

What chance does Nader have in November of breaking the present political mould? Though history is a poor guide to political prediction, it would be very surprising if Nader made much impact. He is not speaking for "forgotten Americans" but for a minority of middle-class voters fed up with meaningless domestic politics.

Perot's share of the vote in 1992 failed to carry a single state, and, by taking more votes from the older George Bush than from his then largely unknown opponent Bill Clinton, Perot helped Clinton's clever and eventually victorious campaign. Eight years later much depends on whether Nader can get himself on the ballot in every state. Even so, American protest voters look more likely to reveal themselves by failing to vote than by casting a protest vote for a third-party activist like Nader.

 Patrick Renshaw is reader in American history at Sheffield University

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Drug deaths up 25%
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The number of drug deaths in Scotland rose by almost a quarter last year despite high profile attempts to tackle the problem.
fields.body:
The number of drug deaths in Scotland rose by almost a quarter last year despite high profile attempts to tackle the problem.

The latest figures, published by the Scottish executive today, reveal that 340 people died from drugs in 1999, compared with 276 in 1998.

Most worrying for the executive is the number of young victims: more than a quarter were under 25.

Angus MacKay, the deputy justice minister, said that with around 20,000 intravenous drug users in Scotland, there could be no hope of an immediate reversal of the trend of recent years.

"Our drugs action plan launched in May anticipated that deaths for 1999 would surpass the 300 mark," he said.

Drug workers put some of the rise down to the volume, purity and relatively low cost of the heroin available.

Mr MacKay said another, less dramatic, rise in deaths was expected this year. Thirty people have already died this year after using a rogue batch of heroin.

While the number of victims aged under 25 is high, the vast majority are aged 25-44. Alistair Ramsay, of Scotland Against Drugs, said this was partly due to a phenomenon known as "bottoming out" - where long-term heroin users hit rock bottom and either come off the drug or die. "That is a problem inherited from a period of 10 to 15 years ago when drug education was not very effective," he said.

Most of Scotland's drug users are concentrated in the Strathclyde police force region - particularly in Glasgow's housing estates.

Grampian had the second highest number of deaths, overtaking Lothian - which includes Edinburgh - with 42 in 1999, up from 31 the year before. Outside the urban centre of Aberdeen much of Grampian's problem is concentrated in Fraserburgh, which has a serious problem with young men, particularly fishermen, becoming heroin addicts.

A spokesman for the Scottish National party said: "The fact that 27% of victims were under 25 shows quite clearly that the Scottish executive has failed this age group."

Deaths among users of methadone - the controversial prescription drug given to addicts trying to quit heroin - fell slightly last year, with 62 people dying, compared with 64 the year before.

fields.headline: The next generation
fields.standfirst: Sky One's new drama series Once and Again has a cast of middle-aged, middle-class divorcees. It's a natural successor to thirtysomething, says  Mark Lawson - glossy, aspirational and none too challenging
fields.trailText: Sky One's new drama series Once and Again has a cast of middle-aged, middle-class divorcees.
fields.body:
When the American drama series thirtysomething was at its peak in the 1980s, a critic observed that the chronological title made the series naturally sequel-friendly. Where thirtysomething followed Hope, Michael, Ethan and the other yuppies through marriage, children and professional ambition, it was easy to imagine a fortysomething in which they got divorced, followed by decadal revisits (like John Updike's sequence of Rabbit novels) until seventysomething tracked them through retirement to the clinic and the grave.

In fact, the 90s passed without a fortysomething but now thirtysomething creators Edward Zwick and Marshall Herskovitz have delivered what is, thematically if not in terms of characters, an update. Sky One's Once and Again frequently looks and sounds like thirtysomething, with the difference that it's a post-marriage drama where the first series was a marriage one.

Rick (Billy Campbell) is an architect and Lily (Sela Ward) a writer. Recent separation or divorce have not prevented them from maintaining cash-hungry homes, clothes and cars. When they meet at a school soccer match, love breaks above their heads like lightning. The opening episode relies heavily on the generational reverses which powered the comedy in Absolutely Fabulous. As Rick and Lily nervously prepare for a date, their teenage children warn them not to have sex before they really know each other. The parents' fumbling attempt to make love is subsequently interrupted when the children come home unexpectedly.

For many watching, this is intended to be the comedy of recognition. Zwick and Herskovitz specialise in what might be called demographic television or mirror fiction. For most of the audience for one of their dramas, what you see is what you've got. They deliver a particular segment of consumers to a network by featuring glossy representatives of the target group - the professional middle-aged middle-classes - in a drama. It was fitting that Michael and Ethan in thirtysomething actually worked in advertising.

Indeed, Zwick and Herskovitz's shows are best understood as compellingly extended advertisements. The people have just too much sheen; the houses always look as if the cleaner has just left after a marathon session. And as for the message they're selling, it's the very American one of redemption and endurance. Their most giveaway piece of typing was when they called the female lead in their biggest series Hope. In thirtysomething, plot-line crises - like adultery, cancer, redundancy, child illness - were all opportunities for the couples to reconnect with each other.

In Once and Again, Rick and Lily have failed these reconnection tests, but the redemptive message is that sheer blinding romantic love is still possible for divorcees with children.

The starting set-up of Once and Again is revealing of the creative team's Madison Avenue instincts. Just as characters in American ads get out of bed in the morning looking beautiful and manicured, so the couple in this drama are, essentially, lovestruck teenagers who just happen to have a wedding wreck behind them; or a tragic widow and widower whose spouses are still distantly alive in the background. This is vital to Once and Again's tone. Because if the central characters were a second-time couple who had left their partners to be together, there would be too great a risk of the audience judging them.

The weakness of these creators - at least to English ears - has always been a certain Reagan-speechwriter cheesiness in their dialogue. Faced with a teenage daughter who considers herself ugly and unlovable and is frightened to go to a party, Lily counsels her: "You are not the miscreant, ugly person you pass yourself off as... Did you ever stop to think that fear might be your friend?"

But the new show fixes Zwick & Herskovitz's position in at least a backroom of US TV's hall of fame. One of the signature strengths of thirtysomething was a stylishness and visual ambition marked by things like the pretentious avoidance of capital letters in the title and the credits.

This narrative flashiness is now routine in US TV - a standard episode of Ally McBeal resembles an especially daring one of thirtysomething in this respect - but Once and Again is lavish with its fantasy sequences and documentary pastiche. As Rick and his ex-wife bicker at parents' night over their son, he is suddenly ambushed by a black and white flashback to the ecstatic night of the child's conception. Between scenes, the central couple footnote their emotions and actions in grainily-shot conversation with an unseen interviewer.

For those who've held on to the satellite dish or cable agreement after the divorce, and can watch Once and Again, the series will make an intriguing if uneasy coupling with BBC1's own autumn post-divorce show: an adaptation of Joanna Trollope's step-family novel Other People's Children. A useful point of distinction between British and American drama is that our shows tend to be admonitory where theirs are aspirational.

British hits make you glad you don't lead the characters' lives. American successes are designed to make you wish that you did. Once and Again proves the point once again.

Once and Again, Thursday, 9.30pm, Sky One.

What's in a name?

TV companies regularly send out press releases about series in production, but two recent media teasers from the BBC were unusually provisional in their information.

The release about a new Stephen Poliakoff series Family Tree stressed that this was merely a "working title". And the PR details for another big new drama series described it as currently "Untitled".

This isn't coincidental. The title of a TV series is thought to have ever more importance in drawing an audience in. Alternative monikers for projects are tried out on focus groups. But despite the attempt to turn titling into a science, it'll always involve luck, and there's always the possibility of bad clashes. (Director Stephen Daldry has just changed the name of his first movie from Dancer to Billy Reilly because of possible confusion with the hit film Dancer in the Dark.)

And we can detect some trends in programme baptism in this week's schedules. Cousins (Wednesday, 8pm, BBC1), Dr Charlotte Uhlenbroek's series about primates, stands out as the first major wildlife series which gives no hint in its title that it involves animals.

This is very much against the recent trend in television in which fears about the audience's intelligence and attention span have led series to wear simple designations like the lapel badges of delegates at a conference. Current examples of such simplicity include Brain Story (Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2) and Battle of Britain (Tuesday,10pm, ITV).

The punning title - a favourite device - is represented by two shows playing on the names of well-known movies: Lamarr's Attacks (Thursday, 9.30pm, BBC2) and Phones, Robbers and Videotape (Wednesday, 10.15pm, BBC1).

But the series which has the most subtle relationship with naming is still Friends (Friday, 9pm, C4). A main title of absolute descriptive simplicity is offset each week by a subtitle in which the writers amusingly play with the way in which fans talk about a show: this week "The One Where Phoebe Runs".

Just as characters in American ads get out of bed in the morning looking beautiful and manicured, so the couple in this drama are, essentially, lovestruck teenagers who just happen to have a wedding wreck behind them; or a tragic widow and widower whose spouses are still distantly alive in the background. This is vital to Once and Again's tone. Because if the central characters were a second-time couple who had left their partners to be together, there would be too great a risk of the audience judging them. The weakness of these creators - at least to English ears - has always been a certain Reagan-speechwriter cheesiness in their dialogue. Faced with a teenage daughter who considers herself ugly and unlovable and is frightened to go to a party, Lily counsels her: "You are not the miscreant, ugly person you pass yourself off as... Did you ever stop to think that fear might be your friend?" But the new show fixes Zwick & Herskovitz's position in at least a backroom of US TV's hall of fame. One of the signature strengths of thirtysomething was a stylishness and visual ambition marked by things like the pretentious avoidance of capital letters in the title and the credits. This narrative flashiness is now routine in US TV - a standard episode of Ally McBeal resembles an especially daring one of thirtysomething in this respect - but Once and Again is lavish with its fantasy sequences and documentary pastiche. As Rick and his ex-wife bicker at parents' night over their son, he is suddenly ambushed by a black and white flashback to the ecstatic night of the child's conception. Between scenes, the central couple footnote their emotions and actions in grainily-shot conversation with an unseen interviewer. For those who've held on to the satellite dish or cable agreement after the divorce, and can watch Once and Again, the series will make an intriguing if uneasy coupling with BBC1's own autumn post-divorce show: an adaptation of Joanna Trollope's step-family novel Other People's Children. A useful point of distinction between British and American drama is that our shows tend to be admonitory where theirs are aspirational. British hits make you glad you don't lead the characters' lives. American successes are designed to make you wish that you did. Once and Again proves the point once again. Once and Again, Thursday, 9.30pm, Sky One. What's in a name? TV companies regularly send out press releases about series in production, but two recent media teasers from the BBC were unusually provisional in their information. The release about a new Stephen Poliakoff series Family Tree stressed that this was merely a "working title". And the PR details for another big new drama series described it as currently "Untitled". This isn't coincidental. The title of a TV series is thought to have ever more importance in drawing an audience in. Alternative monikers for projects are tried out on focus groups. But despite the attempt to turn titling into a science, it'll always involve luck, and there's always the possibility of bad clashes. (Director Stephen Daldry has just changed the name of his first movie from Dancer to Billy Reilly because of possible confusion with the hit film Dancer in the Dark.) And we can detect some trends in programme baptism in this week's schedules. Cousins (Wednesday, 8pm, BBC1), Dr Charlotte Uhlenbroek's series about primates, stands out as the first major wildlife series which gives no hint in its title that it involves animals. This is very much against the recent trend in television in which fears about the audience's intelligence and attention span have led series to wear simple designations like the lapel badges of delegates at a conference. Current examples of such simplicity include Brain Story (Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2) and Battle of Britain (Tuesday,10pm, ITV). The punning title - a favourite device - is represented by two shows playing on the names of well-known movies: Lamarr's Attacks (Thursday, 9.30pm, BBC2) and Phones, Robbers and Videotape (Wednesday, 10.15pm, BBC1). But the series which has the most subtle relationship with naming is still Friends (Friday, 9pm, C4). A main title of absolute descriptive simplicity is offset each week by a subtitle in which the writers amusingly play with the way in which fans talk about a show: this week "The One Where Phoebe Runs".

webTitle: Channel 4 anxious over film crew held in Liberia

fields.headline: Channel 4 anxious over film crew held in Liberia
fields.trailText: A Channel 4 film crew held in Liberia on suspicion of spying waited yesterday to hear whether they would face trial.
fields.body:
A Channel 4 film crew held in Liberia on suspicion of spying waited yesterday to hear whether they would face trial.

British director David Barrie, cameraman Tim Lambon, South African cameraman Gugulakhe Radebe, and Sierra Leonean film-maker Sorious Samura have been held in a police station in the capital Monrovia since Friday. They had arrived three weeks ago, working for a London company, Insight News Television, commissioned by Channel 4 for a political documentary series, Sorious Samura's Africa.

Liberia's justice minister, Eddington Varmah, said they had "engaged in acts against the security of the state" and were arrested on suspicion of espionage. He accused them of trying to denigrate the president, Charles Taylor, and of assisting foreign powers in their diplomatic confrontation with Liberia through "allegations of diamond smuggling, gun running, support to the RUF [Sierra Leone rebels] and human rights abuses". Investigators had evidence that could be presented in court, he said.

Channel 4 yesterday denied the allegations and stated that the crew, for whom it was "deeply concerned", were engaged in "legitimate journalistic activities". A spokesman said there was a strong possibility that a court hearing could take place as early as today, and that a Liberian lawyer had been engaged to represent the four in that event. He added that the crew had written permission to film from the ministry of information.

The UK honorary consul visited the four on Saturday, and reported them fit and well.

fields.headline: Russian navy had no divers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The Russian rescue operation to save crew members trapped in the Kursk submarine was doomed from the start because the navy did not have a deep-sea diving team, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Russian rescue operation to save crew members trapped in the Kursk submarine was doomed from the start because the navy did not have a deep-sea diving team, it was disclosed yesterday.

Even though the Russian public had been led to believe that Moscow had tried in good faith to save the men, it was nevertheless already angry that it took President Putin four days to call for foreign help.

But now it is clear that all the Russian attempts to save the crew were futile. The Bester mini-sub sent down to examine the Kursk could never have locked its "skirt" on to the submarine without divers to guide it by hand.

The Soviet Union had teams of deep-sea navy divers trained in underwater rescue, but the cash-strapped Russian navy was unable to keep them and they were disbanded.

Last night Russian submariners were coming forward to denounce the authorities. "Without divers it is impossible to save the sailors who were suffocating in their grave and everything that's been going in the Barents sea is pure fiction," Yuri Filchenkov, a former navy diver who has worked on oil rigs, told the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. He said he rang the navy several times to offer his experience as a diver when he learned of the sinking.

"Without divers, the submersible would have been banging its head on the side like a blind kitten," another Russian submariner said yesterday.

The crew's families were given false hope because early Russian press reports talked of a diving bell going down to the submarine. But if this confusion was caused by Russian journalists, the naval authorities never put them right.

"From the press and TV reports in the first days we concluded that everything was going according to the usual practice in disasters at such depths. To start with, divers go down with a bell, determine the character of the damage, make a general assessment and then a decision is taken how to conduct the rescue.

"But from the latest announcements it seems that the Norwegians are the first divers to reach the submarine and our people tried to dock their capsule without divers. We are stunned," Igor Kozyr, a retired navy captain from the St Petersburg Submariners' Club told the Guardian last night.

According to Mr Filchenkov, the Northern Fleet - to which the Kursk belonged - had a proper rescue service 15 years ago. It had three rescue ships with equipment including diving bells. The bells, which act like lifts, are pulled up and down by a mother ship with the divers inside them.

"The fact that the Kursk was lying more than 100 metres [328ft] under the surface was no problem in those days. We have lifted sunken ships up from 200 metres," Mr Filchenkov said.

What is not clear from the latest disclosures is whether President Putin himself was properly informed about the navy's problems. If it turns out that he was also deceived by the admirals when they claimed their equipment was up to the task, naval heads may roll when the full inquest into the tragedy is conducted.

Whatever the outcome, observers in Moscow believe the fallout from this disaster is going to be far reaching, for Mr Putin's leadership is under question, as well as the veracity and competence of the naval high command.

webTitle: Rescuers struggle to open escape hatch

fields.headline: Rescuers struggle to open escape hatch
fields.standfirst:
Submarine drama Norwegian and Russian teams at odds over how to continue with deep-sea mission

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Norwegian deep sea divers were battling last night to open a hatch on the stricken Russian submarine, Kursk, after a day in which Russian and Norwegian rescuers openly contradicted each other about the possibility of continuing the rescue mission.
fields.body:
Norwegian deep sea divers were battling last night to open a hatch on the stricken Russian submarine, Kursk, after a day in which Russian and Norwegian rescuers openly contradicted each other about the possibility of continuing the rescue mission.

Denying a Russian report that the escape hatch was too badly cracked to open, a spokesman for the Norwegian armed forces said the hatch could be opened with the help of a mini-submarine.

"We have not drawn the conclusion that the hatch is so damaged that it cannot be opened," John Espen Lien, spokesman for the Norwegian armed forces, said after a team of three Norwegian divers inspected the crippled vessel.

"The hatch is not destroyed and is in a fair condition. We think it should be possible to open it with a British or a Russian rescue capsule."

But the Russian deputy prime minister, Ilya Klebanov, leading a commission of inquiry, said the hatch was so badly damaged it would have to be torn off and that a decision had been made to use a crane on the Norwegian rescue ship to achieve this.

There was also disagreement about whether there was air in the compartment behind the hatch. Russian reports said that the chamber was probably flooded, with a sailor apparently trapped inside. Russia says there is scant hope of finding any of the 118 crew alive.

The Norwegian divers, who have many years' experience working with oil rigs in the North Sea, found that a valve in the submarine's escape hatch had been opened from the inside, indicating that a crew member had tried to get out, Mr Klebanov said. But there was no indication of whether anyone was in the escape chamber.

The British mini-submarine, a type LR5, waited on the surface as the Norwegian divers knocked on the Kursk's hull to see if there was air inside.

President Putin, who cut short a holiday by the Black Sea on Saturday to return to Moscow, met a group of Orthodox church leaders shortly after they had led a service canonising Russia's last Tsar.

But although he decided to ask for foreign help for the Kursk in the wake of a public clamour for action in Russia, Mr Putin's remarks to the clerics, at least as reported by the news agency Interfax, did not mention any specific thanks from him to outsiders.

"We are all following the tragedy with an aching heart and, without any exaggeration, with tears in our eyes. I want to thank everyone who is helping to cope with our common misfortune, including you clergymen for your sympathy and prayers," Mr Putin said.

The President appeared to be trying to exonerate the Russian authorities for blame when he added: "Unfortunately sometimes events, and not we ourselves, dictate the logic of developments."

There is still no clear explanation for the disaster but Mr Klebanov said yesterday that a collision with a foreign vessel or a second world war mine was the most likely cause.

He said that the submarine's front five or six compartments were flooded within seconds. Some crew might have survived for a while in the back three compartments.

The US navy, which had two submarines in the area at the time, said none of its vessels was involved in the incident.

A Norwegian video camera was first lowered yesterday to survey the hull, and the water was checked for possible radiation leaks from the Kursk's two nuclear reactors, officials said.

With little hope left of finding any survivors, the Russian naval authorities have started to plan how to lift the sunken craft to the surface.

They admit they will need foreign help to raise it. The Northern fleet's six pontoons were being prepared, but they did not have enough power to lift the massive waterlogged vessel, Mr Klebanov said.

The last time a nuclear submarine sank, when the Komsomolets went down in 1989, it was left to rust at the bottom of the sea. The bodies of the men who died in that accident were never recovered.

Russian television said the Norwegians had offered to go into the submarine if they could wrench the hatch off.

It would be highly risky work and any member of the team who felt unwilling would not be asked to do it. But the chance that they could find anyone still alive in an air pocket is minimal.
