webTitle: Letters: Let the train take the strain - if you can afford it

fields.headline: Let the train take the strain - if you can afford it
fields.trailText: In the 1960s a prime cause of disaffection in Derry was the foolish decision to close the railway connecting the city with Omagh and Portadown. Recent announcements of largesse towards public transport may have given the impression that New Labour has at last shaken off the Treasury's malignity towards the railways, but northern Irish events show that little has in fact changed.
fields.body:
In the 1960s a prime cause of disaffection in Derry was the foolish decision to close the railway connecting the city with Omagh and Portadown. Recent announcements (Another age of the train? August 18) of largesse towards public transport may have given the impression that New Labour has at last shaken off the Treasury's malignity towards the railways, but northern Irish events show that little has in fact changed. Proposals are afoot to close, not simply to mothball, the lines from Ballymena to Derry (with the Portrush branch) and from Whitehead to Larne.

The effects of the closures upon tourism and social cohesion would be serious - as in the past - and inexcusable in view of the lavish investment in the road system. The contemplated closure beyond Whitehead is doubly deplorable, since the Stranraer-Larne-Rosslare-Cork corridor has been designated as a Euroroute. Such routes, by definition, require the provision of facilities for rail freight on economic, social and environmental grounds.

The proposals originate in the chauffeur-driven oligarchy of the Treasury. It is to be hoped there will be strong opposition to them throughout these islands.

GL Huxley
Church Enstone, Oxon

 We know this is the silly season, but does the Social Exclusion Unit know what the rail regulator is doing? Just as the government promotes rail travel (to facilitate social inclusion and reduce pollution, congestion and so on), it is allowing train companies to cease to offer £2 flat-rate fares for children and instead to charge child passengers a percentage of the adult fare.

This will increase travel costs to those using railcards to travel with children. And, as the DETR will tell you, a disproportionate number of parents have low incomes as do a large number of railcard users, many of whom are too poor to own cars. Joined-up government? What's that?

Professor John Whitelegg
Liverpool John Moores University

Dr Amanda Root
University of Warwick, Coventry

 What with bus lanes, cycle lanes and pedestrianisation, more and more road space is being stolen from motorists. Now it seems people can opt for "home zones" which effectively stop through traffic in a small area of roads and divert it to already congested main roads.

Those selfish people wanting home zones want to transfer their perceived problems of traffic and parking on to other neighbouring areas. If home zones become popular, I suggest we also hand over the responsibility and cost of maintenance and road-sweeping to the residents of such areas. If they want to "privatise" their roads then buy them from the state! Why should the motoring public, who already pay four times more in tax than is spent on roads, continue paying for roads they can't use?

Joe Page
London

fields.headline: Name and blame
fields.trailText: Does Elaine Showalter (Name fame, Saturday Review, August 19) really believe the weekly publication of newborn children's names in the American press indicates US tolerance towards ethnic groups and cultural diversity?
fields.body:
Does Elaine Showalter (Name fame, Saturday Review, August 19) really believe the weekly publication of newborn children's names in the American press indicates US tolerance towards ethnic groups and cultural diversity? From the names she quotes (Lovely Candy, Precious Titanya, Sincere Lamont) I can only imagine that they owe more to their parents' inventiveness than to their ethnicity. Here, in the great melting pot that is South Lanarkshire, I have come across many names that appear to be a celebration of ethnicity: Jade, Ali, Trixybell, Florence Amelia. Unfortunately, most belong to pale-skinned Scots who have never ventured further south than Blackpool.

Robert U Armour
East Kilbride, Lanarkshire robert@uarmour.fsnet.co.uk

 I'm glad Jim White (Manor offers a bad example, August 19) has brought attention to Oxford United's inaction over Ross Weatherstone, the player convicted after an incident where an Asian taxi driver was assaulted in his cab. Both fans' websites have called for him to be expelled, and fans' representatives condemned United in the media. But no mention appears on the club website, not even its own statement. United is a signatory to Kick Racism Out Of Football. But a club thinks that once it has made a commitment to anti-racism, its job is already done. This shames long-term supporters who see their club slight the Asian community.

Justin Horton
Letchworth, Herts

In the same week that the Guardian reports the sale of a "three-room cave" (August 16) for £10,000, the Big Issue reports that homeless people are once again sleeping in caves beneath Nottingham castle. Would that they knew the potential value of their "property".

Dept of city and regional planning, Cardiff University

 Vivien Northcote asks incredulously: "Why do so many people doubt the truth of Christianity?" (Face to Faith, August 19). Has it not occurred to her that many of us find it not only incredible but increasingly sinister, too?

London

 It has been curious to see so many rightwingers deploring hard work. But then, it must be galling that so many oiks are now getting A-levels. It can't be because they too have brains - that's it, A-levels are getting easier!

John Wright
Cockermouth, Cumbria

fields.headline: The donor's dilemma
fields.trailText: Sarah Boseley (Transplant row over pain rule, August 19) does well to expose the lottery for anaesthesia for organ donors over the past 20 years. In addition to the brainstem tests not excluding residual brain activity, recent work suggests that they may sometimes cause death.
fields.body:
Sarah Boseley (Transplant row over pain rule, August 19) does well to expose the lottery for anaesthesia for organ donors over the past 20 years. In addition to the brainstem tests not excluding residual brain activity, recent work suggests that they may sometimes cause death. The tests require a normal body temperature and a high carbon dioxide level, both of which may be enough to destroy damaged brain tissue that could survive if treated by cooling and a low carbon dioxide level. Altruistic donors deserve more honest and better treatment.

Dr David J Hill
Huntingdon

 The report that organ donors judged "brainstem dead" are not routinely anaesthetised fills me with horror. As a transplant recipient, I can only be thankful that I got my transplant at a Catholic European hospital and not in this Godless country. I believe the UK organ transplant service should be taken out of the hands of its present medical and surgical directors. They have failed abysmally to win public confidence for organ transplantation.

The assertion that transplant numbers are going up is misleading. The number of solid organ transplants has declined. The number of kidney transplants, which have the highest success rates, is in sharp decline. Ten years ago there were 1,875 kidney transplants; five years ago there were 1,795; the 1998 figure was 1,530; and last year the figure was down again to 1,476. Likewise, heart transplants have declined from 349 in 1990 to 236 last year.

The UK service is in crisis. Your report will destroy many people who let their child's or their loved one's organs go for transplantation. Such barbarism was not what they signed up to. Unless the Department of Health publishes new guidelines immediately, the loudest noise over the next few months will be the ripping up of donor cards.

Chris Davies
Salford

 "If you are dead, you are dead and ... don't require anaesthesia," says Giles Morgan. That is one hell of an "if". As someone who, in the last year, has signed the relevant authorisations for transplant material gathering from a loved one, and who since that day has wondered whether he did the right thing, I can only ask yet again: "What have I done?" I suspect I'm not alone.

Until anaesthesia is given as a matter of course, my own donor card goes in the bin. Neither will I be signing any more authorisations.

Colin Clarke
Oxford

webTitle: Blarney belies brains on brink of £1bn triumph

fields.headline: Blarney belies brains on brink of £1bn triumph
fields.standfirst: One drops pearls of homespun wisdom; the other is a jet-setting dynamo. Together with a little rubber ring they've built a £976m pharmaceuticals business in Northern Ireland - and the shares are heading upwards
fields.trailText: One drops pearls of homespun wisdom; the other is a jet-setting dynamo. Together with a little rubber ring they've built a £976m pharmaceuticals business in Northern Ireland - and the shares are heading upwards
fields.body:
Just down the road from the sectarian battleground of Drumcree lurks a collection of bleak, breezeblock laboratories. They house the head office of Galen Holdings - a low profile health care firm which is on the brink of becoming Northern Ireland's first £1bn company.

Galen, which was worth just £180m on flotation three years ago, ended last week with a market capitalisation of £976m, and the shares are heading upwards. The only other Ulster business to approach the billion mark is the local electricity supplier, Viridian.

The driving force behind Galen's success is a little rubber loop - called an intra-vaginal ring. Developed in the company's laboratories in nearby Larne, this has been hyped as the future for drug delivery - particularly for hormone replacement therapy. The ring stays in place for up to three months, gradually releasing medicine, and is considered much more convenient than daily pills or cumbersome surgical implants.

The rubber ring has catapulted Galen's management duo, Allen McClay and John King, into the realms of the world's super-rich - their combined 54% stake in the business is worth £530m.

McClay, 67, who founded the company in 1968, is an unlikely pioneer in the field of sexual medicine. Unmarried, he lives in a modest bungalow in Cookstown - the community in which he grew up - with his elderly sister.

McClay rarely gives interviews but over lunch, he demonstrates a decent line in homely wisdom, describing Galen's growth as a process of "building skyscrapers from little bricks".

When the subject of his £340m paper wealth crops up, McClay insists he has little use for money: "The Lord gives nuts to those who have no teeth."

Behind the blarney, locals say McClay hides a highly tuned competitive instinct. One local journalist remarks: "He may sound like a small-town bumpkin but he's as sharp as nails."

In fact, McClay has distributed more than £100m of shares to employees in the business over the years. His own remaining funds are largely invested in charitable trusts, supporting medical research at Queen's University, Belfast, and other academic institutions.

Most promising product
A former salesman for Glaxo Wellcome, McClay began the business as the province's first drugs group - in the early years, Galen was marketed as "Galen Holdings, the Northern Irish pharmaceuticals company".

The company has evolved into two distinct divisions - a drugs manufacturing operation and a business providing contract research and development services for other pharmaceuticals groups.

Galen's in-house research is limited to drug delivery techniques - the intra-vaginal ring is its most promising product, awaiting the green light from regulators by the end of the year. A second type of product, whereby medicine is absorbed from a patch on the skin, is in the earlier stages of research.

Chief executive John King says the strategy has been to develop profitable business with research as a sideline: "We don't have the resources to be the next Glaxo Wellcome. We have to be very selective in the way we target our research.

"We're not like some biotech companies with no earnings and no profits, depending on one possible multimillion-pound product. Our business doesn't depend on the intra-vaginal ring. We have a core business underneath it."

King, 50, has been part of the business since 1979 - he was previously a lecturer in the pharmacy department of Queen's University. His stake in Galen is valued at £190m, and he is the jet-setting half of the management duo, spending half his time in the US and dividing his home life between flats in Belfast and Dublin.

Despite Galen's efforts to play down the IVR, it is the key to the company's short-term health. Galen is about to conclude a £190m takeover of Warner Chilcott, a US pharmaceuticals firm which was largely conceived in order to provide a salesforce for the IVR in the US.

The deal will take Galen into the big time on the international drugs scene: it even brings in Bill Gates as a shareholder - he is an investor in Warner Chilcott, and he will have 3% of the combined organisation. McClay says: "I've never met him. Perhaps he could use some advice."

The next logical step is to buy a European operation in order to add a continental salesforce. A proposed £1.5bn merger with a French group, Ferring Pharmaceuticals, collapsed two years ago amid stock market turbulence. King says: "We're really focused on internationalising the business."

King and McClay share an office and consult each other on all important decisions. King says: "He shouts at me. I don't really shout at him." After the Warner Chilcott deal, McClay will become non-executive president - although colleagues say there is little doubt that he will continue turning up for work every day.

Studies in libido
Galen's activities have attracted surprisingly little attention, given their potentially controversial nature in a divided society. The IVR's potential applications include delivering testosterone for increasing the sex drive of menopausal women - effectively, working as a female version of Viagra. The company's researchers have been rounding up Ulster's womenfolk and carrying out detailed studies of their libido.

So has the company ever come into conflict with Ulster's puritanical streak? McClay is dismissive: "I don't know what books you've been reading but Northern Ireland is not a religious society. The conflict here is about politics, not religion."

What about the followers of the Reverend Ian Paisley? McClay snaps: "Paisley is a nonentity."

Galen is very keen to position itself as an apolitical, non-religious organisation, given its position on the outskirts of Drumcree. A bright orange windsock flutters from the roof of its head office but King insists: "That's for health and safety reasons." The troubles down the road have had little evident effect - although one employee remarks that the Drumcree stand-off was a popular excuse for a day off as members of staff claimed they could not get into work. Although they insist that Northern Ireland's troubled have had no effect on the business, both McClay and King are reluctant to have their photographs taken "for security reasons".

McClay's accumulated wealth puts him among the richest few individuals on the Emerald Isle - ahead of such celebrities as Van Morrison and Chris de Burgh. The company is very much his baby - he chose the name to commemorate Claudius Galen, an ancient Greek pharmacist, but also "because it contains a bit of the name Allen".

There is a culture of share ownership throughout Galen - McClay says many junior staff keep a close watch on the company's price on the stock market: "I'll be coming down the stairs and the receptionist will say to me: 'it's dropped tuppence - what have you been doing'?"

So will passing the £1bn mark merit a celebration for the organisation? "I shouldn't think so," says McClay. "We can't afford it."

The only other Ulster business to approach the billion mark is the local electricity supplier, Viridian. The driving force behind Galen's success is a little rubber loop - called an intra-vaginal ring. Developed in the company's laboratories in nearby Larne, this has been hyped as the future for drug delivery - particularly for hormone replacement therapy. The ring stays in place for up to three months, gradually releasing medicine, and is considered much more convenient than daily pills or cumbersome surgical implants. The rubber ring has catapulted Galen's management duo, Allen McClay and John King, into the realms of the world's super-rich - their combined 54% stake in the business is worth £530m. McClay, 67, who founded the company in 1968, is an unlikely pioneer in the field of sexual medicine. Unmarried, he lives in a modest bungalow in Cookstown - the community in which he grew up - with his elderly sister. McClay rarely gives interviews but over lunch, he demonstrates a decent line in homely wisdom, describing Galen's growth as a process of "building skyscrapers from little bricks". When the subject of his £340m paper wealth crops up, McClay insists he has little use for money: "The Lord gives nuts to those who have no teeth." Behind the blarney, locals say McClay hides a highly tuned competitive instinct. One local journalist remarks: "He may sound like a small-town bumpkin but he's as sharp as nails." In fact, McClay has distributed more than £100m of shares to employees in the business over the years. His own remaining funds are largely invested in charitable trusts, supporting medical research at Queen's University, Belfast, and other academic institutions. Most promising product A former salesman for Glaxo Wellcome, McClay began the business as the province's first drugs group - in the early years, Galen was marketed as "Galen Holdings, the Northern Irish pharmaceuticals company". The company has evolved into two distinct divisions - a drugs manufacturing operation and a business providing contract research and development services for other pharmaceuticals groups. Galen's in-house research is limited to drug delivery techniques - the intra-vaginal ring is its most promising product, awaiting the green light from regulators by the end of the year. A second type of product, whereby medicine is absorbed from a patch on the skin, is in the earlier stages of research. Chief executive John King says the strategy has been to develop profitable business with research as a sideline: "We don't have the resources to be the next Glaxo Wellcome. We have to be very selective in the way we target our research. "We're not like some biotech companies with no earnings and no profits, depending on one possible multimillion-pound product. Our business doesn't depend on the intra-vaginal ring. We have a core business underneath it." King, 50, has been part of the business since 1979 - he was previously a lecturer in the pharmacy department of Queen's University. His stake in Galen is valued at £190m, and he is the jet-setting half of the management duo, spending half his time in the US and dividing his home life between flats in Belfast and Dublin. Despite Galen's efforts to play down the IVR, it is the key to the company's short-term health. Galen is about to conclude a £190m takeover of Warner Chilcott, a US pharmaceuticals firm which was largely conceived in order to provide a salesforce for the IVR in the US. The deal will take Galen into the big time on the international drugs scene: it even brings in Bill Gates as a shareholder - he is an investor in Warner Chilcott, and he will have 3% of the combined organisation. McClay says: "I've never met him. Perhaps he could use some advice." The next logical step is to buy a European operation in order to add a continental salesforce. A proposed £1.5bn merger with a French group, Ferring Pharmaceuticals, collapsed two years ago amid stock market turbulence. King says: "We're really focused on internationalising the business." King and McClay share an office and consult each other on all important decisions. King says: "He shouts at me. I don't really shout at him." After the Warner Chilcott deal, McClay will become non-executive president - although colleagues say there is little doubt that he will continue turning up for work every day. Studies in libido Galen's activities have attracted surprisingly little attention, given their potentially controversial nature in a divided society. The IVR's potential applications include delivering testosterone for increasing the sex drive of menopausal women - effectively, working as a female version of Viagra. The company's researchers have been rounding up Ulster's womenfolk and carrying out detailed studies of their libido. So has the company ever come into conflict with Ulster's puritanical streak? McClay is dismissive: "I don't know what books you've been reading but Northern Ireland is not a religious society. The conflict here is about politics, not religion." What about the followers of the Reverend Ian Paisley? McClay snaps: "Paisley is a nonentity." Galen is very keen to position itself as an apolitical, non-religious organisation, given its position on the outskirts of Drumcree. A bright orange windsock flutters from the roof of its head office but King insists: "That's for health and safety reasons." The troubles down the road have had little evident effect - although one employee remarks that the Drumcree stand-off was a popular excuse for a day off as members of staff claimed they could not get into work. Although they insist that Northern Ireland's troubled have had no effect on the business, both McClay and King are reluctant to have their photographs taken "for security reasons". McClay's accumulated wealth puts him among the richest few individuals on the Emerald Isle - ahead of such celebrities as Van Morrison and Chris de Burgh. The company is very much his baby - he chose the name to commemorate Claudius Galen, an ancient Greek pharmacist, but also "because it contains a bit of the name Allen". There is a culture of share ownership throughout Galen - McClay says many junior staff keep a close watch on the company's price on the stock market: "I'll be coming down the stairs and the receptionist will say to me: 'it's dropped tuppence - what have you been doing'?" So will passing the £1bn mark merit a celebration for the organisation? "I shouldn't think so," says McClay. "We can't afford it."

fields.headline: The really big tiger's tale
fields.trailText: If the British newspapers are right, the Irish economy is in serious trouble. British commentators are convinced that we are headed for a severe recession.
fields.body:
If the British newspapers are right, the Irish economy is in serious trouble. British commentators are convinced that we are headed for a severe recession.

Some base their belief on a simple appeal to the notion that what goes up must come down. Others discern portents of doom in some of the recent trends. They have a point.

Inflation is now running at 6.2%, wage inflation is accelerating sharply and house prices have risen by about 20% per annum over the past three years. On the face of it, this seems like a recipe for a rough hangover. But is it?

Take consumer prices. Inflation in a very open economy like Ireland, where exports and imports amount to 170% of GDP, is mostly a reflection of international influences and exchange rate changes.

Thus, of the 3.5% point acceleration in inflation since July last year - the core rate has increased from 2.4% to 5.9% over this period - 1.2 points are due to rising world energy prices and 1.1 points to the weak euro. Much of the remainder is due to a hefty rise in tobacco duty. So it would be quite mistaken to regard the RPI as a barometer of overheating in Ireland, or to interpret its recent behaviour as a harbinger of gloom.

It would be disingenuous to deny that the RPI reflects do mestic inflationary pressures to some extent. The services component of the index is rising at a vigorous 7% annual rate. It is due to wage inflation, of course: the services sector is labour intensive and sheltered from international competition. But, is wage inflation in the vicinity of 7% the precursor of recession?

Pessimists answer "yes" on the grounds that it will undermine the economy's competitiveness. But Ireland has become a hyper-competitive economy and must become less competitive if output growth is to moderate to a sustainable rate. When there is a labour shortage, wages must rise until the shortage is eliminated. It is not necessary that anything be lost in this process except the surfeit of competitiveness that caused the demand for labour to exceed supply in the first place.

So, is there nothing that can go wrong? Well, it is possible that wages will rise so steeply and competitiveness be so massively eroded that output and employment will fall. For this to happen would require a labour market in which employees exercised bargaining power way above that which the operation of free market forces confers on them.

This is improbable in an economy where only 25%-30% of the private sector workforce is unionised, and where work ers in the most dynamic sectors are not unionised at all.

As for the persistence of double-digit house price inflation, one must distinguish cause and effect. Not even in the UK in the early 1990s was the collapse in house prices the cause of recession. It was a consequence of a recession rooted in a weakening of the world economy and a sharp tightening of British macroeconomic policy.

It makes no sense to argue that a fall in house prices (itself an improbable event in the absence of some deterioration in the economic environment) would cause a recession in Ireland.

Even assuming that consumer spending would weaken in response, the very high propensity to import (Ireland imports virtually all its cars and consumer durables) would mean that the impact on output would be small.

The main determinant of long-term growth in the Irish economy is the size of its export base. Given that internal resources are limited, expan sion of that base relies heavily on foreign direct investment. A key barometer of the health of the economy, therefore, is the rate of inflow of foreign investment. Here the indications are that Ireland's rapid expansion will continue for quite some time.

Even in recent weeks there has been a flood of announcements by leading international information technology firms - Intel, IBM, Cisco Systems, Microsoft, to name a few - of their intention to expand existing facilities or establish greenfield operations in Ireland.

The Irish economy stories that have dominated the media of late have been those of runaway inflation. In my view, the really big story is that, despite rising costs, Ireland continues to prove irresistibly attractive to global hi-tech firms.

It seems that Ireland, in a European context, is moving towards the kind of position that regions like Seattle and Silicon Valley occupy in the US - a dynamic hi-tech pole that specialises in a range of knowledge-intensive activities and enjoys much higher than average productivity and living standards. Higher than average production and living costs are just part of that territory.

Jim O'Leary is chief economist of Davy Stockbrokers in Dublin

fields.headline: Big spender faces bumpy ride
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is on honeymoon with Sarah and the voters. It's not just the understated, spin-free wedding that has impressed. Judging by Labour's post-spending review poll readings, they also adore him for pouring so much extra money - £43bn - into key public services.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is on honeymoon with Sarah and the voters. It's not just the understated, spin-free wedding that has impressed. Judging by Labour's post-spending review poll readings, they also adore him for pouring so much extra money - £43bn - into key public services. Meanwhile, the economy, Labour's most valuable electoral asset, quietly goes from strength to strength.

The Chancellor may be thousands of miles away, canoodling with his wife in Cape Cod, but he could not fail to have been cheered by last week's economic data and their favourable electoral implications.

While unemployment fell to 1,070,000 in July, and at this rate will soon dip below the million mark, underlying inflation inflation held steady at 2.2% and wage growth eased from 4.6% to 4.1%, comfortably below the Bank of England's 4.5% speed limit.

This at a time when the world economy is experiencing an oil price shock which, in the past, could have been sufficient to plunge it into recession.

It's hard to imagine a better platform from which to launch a general election campaign. Whatever the cause of Britain's economic nirvana - skilful handling of macroeconomic policy or good luck or a combination of the two - Mr Brown and the government will take the credit on polling day. No wonder William "14-pints" Hague has been driven to drink. With everything going so well, it's natural that exponents of the dismal science should ask: where could it all go wrong?

High on the list of disaster scenarios is the US economy going belly-up. It's been so often predicted that people automatically switch off when the subject is mentioned and the most recent data releases, showing accelerating productivity and subdued inflation, certainly give no comfort to the merchants of doom. But the risk of a hard landing caused by an asset price correction remains a very real threat to global and UK economic stability. The new economy may be able to grow much faster and for longer before running into the buffers, but the laws of supply and demand have not been repealed and it can only be a matter of time before the US economy overheats unless the pace of growth moderates soon.

The pound also remains a wild card. Fears of meltdown in manufacturing may have receded as some firms learn to live with a strong currency, but anecdotal evidence suggests that there are many more hanging on for dear life. While they own plant in this country and believe that sterling's overvaluation is temporary, manufacturers are likely to carrying on producing their goods even at vastly reduced profit margins, but faced with a new investment decision they may move elsewhere if they can see no respite from the pain they are enduring.

The Danish EMU referendum on September 28, if it is lost, could well undermine the euro and give another leg-up to sterling on the foreign exchanges, speeding the flow of job losses in Labour heartlands. While this will not derail the recovery, it could well have electoral implications. Although it will not prompt heartland voters to switch to the Tories, a sense of disillusionment with the government could prompt them to stay at home on polling day, giving the Conservatives seats by default.

The down side risks to the economic outlook should not be overplayed. According to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, which has one of the best forecasting records, the chances of a full-blown recession next year are only 3%. The real threat to stability lies in the opposite direction.

The Chancellor's public spending plans were formulated on the basis that, after peaking this year, economic growth will gradually slow under the combined weight of the strong pound and four quarter-point interest rate rises since last September.

As consumer spending flagged, room would be created for public spending to take up the slack without putting upward pressure on inflation. However, with the autumn approaching, there is no hard evidence that domestic demand is slowing significantly.

True, the housing market has come off the boil but it is still robust, and consumer confidence is being underpinned by rising real incomes and rapidly falling unemployment. Consumers are about to receive a fresh boost from a new wave of windfalls flowing from the demutualisation of the Bradford & Bingley building society and various life assurance companies, including Scottish Widows, Friends Provident and Scottish Provident.

Spendthrift consumers
With nominal interest rates still very low, it's not hard to imagine a scenario in which - far from retrenching - the consumer comes back from his holiday in a spendthrift mood. At the same time the economy's capacity to grow is being tested by buoyant IT-related business investment, albeit confined to the service sector.

The optimistic interpretation of last week's figures, the one that is likely to prevail in the short term, is that there has been a dramatic improvement in the trade-off between inflation and unemployment. But the ex-bonus earnings data was less comforting, showing a decline to 4.4% from 4.6%.

The pessimists - or should that be realists? - on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee may think the latest earnings data, still subject to uncertainty after the recent overhaul, represents the calm before the storm. While admitting it's possible we really are living in an era where inflation expectations have permanently adjusted downwards, conditioning workers to expect pay rises of between 3% and 4% from here to eternity, the inflation hawks no doubt continue to live in fear of a wage-price spiral.

Geoff Dicks, of Royal Bank of Scotland, points out that this year's wage claims were based on headline rates of inflation of less than 2% at the end of 1999. Next year, they will be based on headline rates of between 3% and 4%. The National Institute says a slight pick-up in average earnings growth to about 6% in 2002 can be afforded because it will be paid for out of higher productivity. In this case, labour costs per unit of output will remain under control and not contribute to any significant increase of inflation. But the expected US-style pick-up in productivity growth is not guaranteed.

The upshot is that while all seems well on the surface, the economy is actually at a very delicate point in the cycle where events could take a turn for the worse. In the late 1980s Nigel Lawson made the mistake of believing he had performed a miracle, cutting taxes and boosting domestic demand just when least needed. The result was a spectacular boom followed by bust.

Mr Brown isn't foolish enough to believe his own publicity, but he has taken a gamble by being so generous on public spending. Although perfectly justifiable on social and economic grounds in the long term, in the short term his largesse could yet contribute to a further round of interest rate rises which would not endear him to homeowners. Borrowing costs won't climb as high as 15%, as they did to control the Lawson boom, but 7% or 8% is perfectly feasible. Voters would not see this as grounds for divorce, but it would spark a few rows between now and polling day.

webTitle: Fed will not wind down the party yet

fields.headline: Fed will not wind down the party yet
fields.trailText:
Are American interest rates likely to rise again this week?
America's central bank, the Federal Reserve, meets tomorrow, and under normal circumstances with inflation running at 3.5%, an interest rate increase would be on the cards. But circumstances are not normal; there is a presidential election in just over two months and many analysts think the Federal Reserve will hold fire until after polling day.
fields.body:
Are American interest rates likely to rise again this week?
America's central bank, the Federal Reserve, meets tomorrow, and under normal circumstances with inflation running at 3.5%, an interest rate increase would be on the cards. But circumstances are not normal; there is a presidential election in just over two months and many analysts think the Federal Reserve will hold fire until after polling day.

Isn't the Federal Reserve supposed to be completely independent from political pressure?

Alan Greenspan didn't get to be one of the world's oldest central bankers by being politically naive; the Democrats would not thank him if he spoiled their best campaigning line - the strength of the US economy - by hinting that it was time for the party to wind down a little. As well as being bad political timing, a rate rise now might well be unnecessary, according to the optimists on the Federal Reserve's open markets committee, which argues that the economy is heading for a soft landing.

What is a soft landing?
The scenario in which the economy slows down of its own accord without the Federal Reserve needing to rein it in with higher borrowing costs. Most economists agree that the US cannot go on growing at this pace - last quarter the economy expanded at an annual rate of more than 5% - without some inflationary strains starting to emerge.

Are there any signs of a slowdown?
The second-quarter figures, even though they show torrid growth, appear to suggest that household spending is slowing down - which is good news for optimists. Job creation appears to be slowing down, too. Other economists argue that the economy may have slowed down, but it is operating way above the speed limit.

What speed limit?
The level of growth consistent with stable inflation. Most economists believe that if an economy grows too fast it will overheat. Pessimists argue that the US has passed that point, and it's time for the Federal Reserve to apply the brakes. It has raised rates six times in the last year, to 6.5%, and they believe at least one more increase is necessary to achieve a slow-down.

What do the optimists say?
That the IT revolution has brought about a step change in economic efficiency, with the result that the economy can expand at a faster rate without generating inflation.

Is there any evidence to back this up?
US productivity levels are at their highest in 17 years. Some sceptics say, however, that the apparent productivity miracle is a mirage which will dissolve when the economy slows down. Productivity tends to accelerate at the peak of an economic cycle because, with all available workers sucked into employment, firms drive their existing workforce harder for longer hours in order to increase output.

So what's the betting for the outcome of tomorrow's meeting?
Almost certainly no change. One thing is for sure though, if Wim Duisenburg and his colleagues at the European Central Bank were to do a job swap with Mr Greenspan and his chums on the Rederal Reserve's rate-setting committee, the Europeans would not hesitate to pull the interest rate trigger. The European Central Bank is almost certain to raise rates next week - and at 2.4%, inflation in Europe is well below American levels.

Some sceptics say, however, that the apparent productivity miracle is a mirage which will dissolve when the economy slows down. Productivity tends to accelerate at the peak of an economic cycle because, with all available workers sucked into employment, firms drive their existing workforce harder for longer hours in order to increase output. So what's the betting for the outcome of tomorrow's meeting? Almost certainly no change. One thing is for sure though, if Wim Duisenburg and his colleagues at the European Central Bank were to do a job swap with Mr Greenspan and his chums on the Rederal Reserve's rate-setting committee, the Europeans would not hesitate to pull the interest rate trigger. The European Central Bank is almost certain to raise rates next week - and at 2.4%, inflation in Europe is well below American levels.

fields.headline: 'It should have energy and a bit of magic. But this is dull'
fields.standfirst:
Is the Edinburgh festival everything it could be under Brian McMaster? According to the expert opinions Brian Logan has gathered, the answer is a resounding no


Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Is the Edinburgh festival everything it could be under Brian McMaster? According to the expert opinions Brian Logan has gathered, the answer is a resounding no.
fields.body:
Two weeks ago Brian McMaster, director of the Edinburgh international festival, was looking ahead to his centrepiece event, the Abbey Theatre revival of Ramon Valle-Inclan's Barbaric Comedies. "We are trying to turn it into a piece of popular, spectacular theatre that talks to a lot of people," he told the Times. "But if we don't pull an audience it could completely fuck the whole future of the festival."

The four-hour Barbaric Comedies is playing to emptying houses. The show is, said the Guardian, "a case of excess run riot". According to the Telegraph, it is "a paradigm or parody of everything that is wrong and rotten about the Edinburgh international festival". So is "the whole future of the festival" now under threat?

Founded in 1948 to foster cultural links after the second world war, the international festival has since been surrounded by a clutch of peripheral events, of which the most prominent and controversial is the fringe festival. So how does the international festival now distinguish itself? According to its mission statement, it aims "to promote and encourage arts of the highest possible standard; to reflect international culture in presentation to Scottish audiences and to reflect Scottish culture in presentation to international audiences; and to bring together a programme of events in an innovative way that cannot easily be achieved by other organisations".

The EIF received £1.9m from Edinburgh City Council and the Scottish Arts Council in 1999, and matched that revenue in ticket sales. Its prominence and financial privilege confers on the festival a responsibility to excel, but there is a wide spread sense - in theatres, in the press, and on the streets of Edinburgh - that it is failing.

So the Guardian canvassed the opinions of Britain's most prominent festival programmers and Edinburgh veterans. Is Brian McMaster's programming good enough? Under what pressures does a festival director labour? And how should the festival position itself in this new century?

Gavin Henderson

Director, Dartington festival

Edinburgh is very much about imported culture. It's not something of which the community feels it has any ownership. Things come to Edinburgh and set up shop: it's a glorified Exchange & Mart of programming. And in Edinburgh, where resources are still not as great as, say, Salzburg, the international festival director has a limited ability to make work from scratch. He's really just a sophisticated magpie popping into his shopping basket a bit of this and a bit of that. Edinburgh does a very limited amount of commissioning, which for me is very disappointing.

I feel that a festival should be the antidote to the global culture - that is, where the specific, the local and the very domestic and personal activity happens. It's the jolt in the routine of artistic activity. A festival should bring people up with a start, not with a feeling of: "Oh, God, they've got that as well, have they?"

Jonathan Reekie

Director, Aldeburgh festival

Festivals are becoming much more global. There's a tendency for large international shows to travel the festival circuit, so a homogeneity is creeping in. One response is to co-produce new work, but that often creates more homogeneity. It would be great if places like Edinburgh did produce more, but we're all working under increasing financial strains and I understand why it might not be able to. I work for a festival that has always been very much defined by its area: by the locality, the people and the culture of Suffolk. Edinburgh is a very special place too. It'd be great to see a stronger sense of the place.

John Drummond

Ex-director, Edinburgh festival

The moment came in my time when the bulk of the audience seemed to be local people. Some 70% of our audience back then lived in Scotland. In terms of Brian McMaster's program ming, it's a bit disappointing to see Pierre Boulez, with the London Symphony Orchestra, repeating the concerts he's already done in London. I think it's a little unambitious. We tried in my time not to do things that had been seen in London. On the other hand, there will be people in Edinburgh who won't have heard those concerts. Twenty years ago governments were terribly thrilled with the idea of people coming, and countries like Germany and France were rolling in money. The communist bloc was very keen to send representatives, and very cheaply too. Now that's all gone.

Stella Hall

Director, Belfast international festival

A festival needs a number of different ingredients to be successful, and if the ingredients include high-profile artists who are touring other festivals, then great. If your audience can't travel to Australia or New York to see that work, then it's part of your responsibility to bring it to them. Brian has been able to specialise with his programming, and to focus on themes and artists in a way that he may not have done had not the fringe, the jazz and blues and the film festivals been going on alongside. One has to respond to circumstance. I think Brian has put together an excellent programme, and a challenging one.

Kenny Ireland

Artistic director, Royal Lyceum

If you programme according to the snob value of the name directors, eventually you'll get their bad production, or a series of bad productions. And then the audiences start thinking: "Actually, I don't like drama." Booking the latest production of Robert Wilson or Zadek for two years hence is a sterile process. You need to be finding what has not yet got a reputation, as well as what has. There's a lot of really good stuff on Brian's doorstep. He, I think, disagrees. Brian has been disparaging about what he sees in Scotland. There is excellence out there and it needs to be managed and brought together.

Lucy Neal

London international festival of theatre

The London international festival of theatre questions the notion of a festival director programming the festival's work. By opening up the curatorial role to different cultural viewpoints, decisions as to who are the international circuit's latest stars would give way to a more robust sense of artistic dialogue. Led by the work of artists, festivals can be catalysts for social and political change. They create a framework for people to learn from different cultures and move between them with more confidence. They are an artistic alternative to a world torn by cultural conflict.

Richard Demarco

Artist and renowned Edinburgh impresario

The millions the international festival receives from funding bodies should be spread out, firstly to com panies that need to feel they're not left out: companies from countries such as Belarus and Georgia. We talk about international festivals, but these people can't come, because they can't afford it. The festival could go to Sarajevo, Dubrovnik and Tbilisi, and inject its energy into these places.

Halfway through this festival we heard reports of horrific things happening in Russia. What's the festival doing about that? Where are the Russian plays? This festival is sick, it's not at ease with itself. We're in danger of destroying one of the most beautiful things Scotland has ever had, a thing that gave it dignity.

Bill Burdett-Coutts

Director, Assembly Rooms

The festival has grown up topsy-turvy and the structure needs a rethink. In the public mind, it is one festival, but in fact, it's seven or eight festivals, and they are tugging against each other. It's a shambles.

The international festival is quite myopic and I'm not sure it makes any effort to get along with anybody else. I like Brian enormously, but it's not in his nature to go out and embrace other people, and it is the duty and responsibility of the international festival to do that. The comments I hear about the international festival programme are that it's rather dull. Festivals should be about a surge of energy and a bit of magic: the last thing they should be is dull.

Philip Howard

Artistic director, Traverse Theatre

What makes some people furious is that the work Brian programmes appears to be inaccessible. Every year the critiques get more savage - "What is he trying to do to us, making us sit through these nine hours?" I think he likes winding everybody up, but I also think he has a genuine belief in the integrity of the work. He is a bastion, someone who believes in the right to see that level of work altogether in a festival, in a way that is totally unfashionable. The fact that audiences aren't always huge for some of these pieces may mean that in five years' time we'll no longer get to see such work. I wonder whether his critics might then be saying: "It's a shame we can't see any of that kind of work any more".

David Sefton

Director of Performing Arts, UCLA

I subscribe to the US presidency model. Festivals should be a reflection of the director's vision, but there should be a finite run for a festival director's term. A healthy model is one that reviews its director's position. I'm just back from Australia, where the Melbourne festival line-up was great. Edinburgh wants to be judged as a world-class festival, but against other festivals it's found wanting.

In some cases, it isn't even bringing in the best people any more. It's not innovating. A huge chunk of the Scottish Arts Council's money, not to mention sponsorship and media attention, is concentrated into those three weeks. The responsible way to deal with that is to be good. Edinburgh isn't good enough.

fields.headline: Arsenal 2 - 0 Liverpool
fields.standfirst: Red alert as Vieira heads exodus
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Arsenal: Seaman, Vieira, Keown, Adams, Pires, Bergkamp, Lauren, Henry, Silvinho, Grimandi, Luzhny. Subs: Dixon, Manninger, Kanu, Cole, Vernazza.

Liverpool: Westerveld, Henchoz, Babbel, Smicer, Heskey, Hyypia, Hamann, Barmby, McAllister, Carragher, Traore. Subs: Song, Owen, Murphy, Meijer, Arphexad.

Referee: Graham Poll (England)

1 Arsenal kick-off and have an early chance when Thierry Henry runs through to the edge of the Liverpool area. He tries to chip Sander Westerveld but the Liverpool keeper spreads himself well and blocks the chance.
3 Liverpool attack on the break with Vladimir Smicer but the ball runs away from him as he reaches the Arsenal area.
4 Nick Barmby runs on to goal and goes down under a challenge from Silvinho but the referee waves play on. On another day...
6 Booking Barmby.
7 Silvinho, on the left of the Liverpool area, lobs the ball to the far side, Lauren picks up and shoots - corner. Looks as though it should have been a goal-kick, however, and Liverpool not best pleased.
8 GOAL: Arsenal 1 - 0 Liverpool It's an in-swinging corner from the right, there's a scramble in the six-yard box and that man Lauren is there again to fire in from close range. Tony Adams shakes his head as if it came off his shin.
13 Liverpool corner. Gary McAllister takes from the right and the ball is cleared off the line.
17 Arsenal free-kick. Silvinho takes and tries to find Patrick Vieira but Liverpool clear. Silvinho plays it back on to the right of the Liverpool area looking for Lauren but the ball out-runs him.
19 Close shave for Liverpool when Stephane Henchoz tackles Vieira on the edge of the area. Arsenal look by far the more lively of the two sides and deserve their lead on the evidence of the first 20 minutes.
25 Arsenal looking very sharp as Denis Bergkamp tries to slide the ball down the right-hand side of the area but there is some confusion among the Arsenal players as to who should be chasing.
26 Henchoz really very lucky to get away without a booking this time when he pulls Robert Pires to the ground via his threads. Ref Poll has a word and Henchoz will now have to watch his step.
30 Vieira finds Henry on the left corner of the area, Henry turns his marker, cuts inside and shots to the far post with his right foot - Westerveld at full stretch to keep the ball out. Corner from the right - goes straight for a corner on the left and that is cleared.
31 A rare moment of offensive action from Liverpool as Sami Hyypia launches a long ball towards Emile Heskey, but the ball runs on to David Seaman. Seaman continues to look silly with that ponytail.
33 Liverpool win a corner on the left, McAllister takes but it goes for another corner from the right. Hyypia gets up but Seaman beats him to it.
36 Booking Dietmar Hamann for a crunching tackle on Lauren.
37 Adams clears for Arsenal, Hamann meets it and heads down, but live wire Lauren is at it again and dispossess Hamann before racing through midfield. The final ball is poor and finds only space.
38 Red card! Off you go. McAllister on his first start as a Liverpool player, for a tackle on Vieira. Harsh as McAllister looked to have got the ball the ball, but ref Poll didn't like the follow through and sent him on his way. However, he missed Gilles Grimandi planting his studs on the grounded McAllister's hand in the aftermath.
42 Great passing move by Arsenal sees the ball fly off the feet off Henry and Silvinho as it covers half the field before beating Pires to the edge of the Liverpool area.
45 Booking Henchoz finally runs out of luck. Four minutes to play. Arsenal win a corner after good work by Smicer on the left. The ball comes to Henry, is knocked square to Grimandi but his shot flies wide of the right-hand upright. Half-time. Arsenal by far the better side (stand up the mercurial Lauren) and Liverpool will have their work cut out with only ten men.

46 Liverpool get the second half underway and the referee blows immediately for a high tackle by Arsenal. Liverpool win a corner from the free-kick but Arsenal clear.
48 Bergkamp gets on the end of a long throw, but he snatches at his shot from the right corner of the area.
49 Smicer does well to find space deep on the left but Markus Babbel stops him in his tracks.
50 Liverpool free-kick, Hamann takes from 30 yards and forces Seaman down to his left. A great clearance by Seaman finds Henry in space but his shot goes for a corner. Two in a row, and both are cleared.
52 Liverpool corner; comes to nothing.
54 Henchoz in trouble again for blocking Henry on a run into the Liverpool area, but he survives.
55 Heskey gets in on the action with a run down the left but he is run off the ball after good covering work by Grimandi.
55 Great move by Arsenal. Henry picks up the ball in midfield, finds Lauren on the right who turns his marker and plays the ball square for the advancing Henry. He is tackled and the ball comes out to Bergkamp on the left but his shot is saved.
60 Liverpool still look no nearer to an equaliser as Arsenal attack again down the right. Lauren and Oleg Luzhny exchange passes but the chance goes begging.
61 Adams almost gets on the scoresheet when Henry finds him in the six-yard box.
62 After a bit of head tennis in the Arsenal area, the ball comes out for Hamann to rifle in a shot from 25 yards. Seaman saves to his right for a corner. Comes to nothing.
65 Arsenal corner. Liverpool have everyone back but Arsenal still manage to get to the loose ball.
67 Liverpool free-kick from midfield. Hamann plays it deep but Arsenal clear.
68 Henry forces a free-kick under pressure from Henchoz. Silvinho wafts it over the wall from 25 yards but Westerveld gathers easily.
70 Substitution Michael Owen on for Smicer. Immediately after the substitution, the handbags come out and both Carragher and Vieira end up with a booking.
74 Red card The red mist descends and Vieira and Carragher almost come to blows again before Vieira lunges in with two-footed tackle, a second bookable offence. Two out of two for The Frenchman, not the ideal start to his season.
75 Booking Bergkamp, after his third foul in succession.
76 Substitution Nwankwo Kanu on for Bergkamp.
77Danny Murphy on for Barmby.
78 Red card Hamann for shirt-pulling, second bookable offence.
80 Substitution Erik Meijer on for Heskey. Owen finally gets a touch.
82 Kanu fights for space on the left and wins a corner. Comes to nothing.
86 Two Liverpool corners in succession, and they fail to make good use of both.
90 GOAL: Arsenal 2 - 0 Liverpool Henry shows true to class as he shimmies his way around Henchoz and shoots into the right corner of the net. Game, set and match to Arsenal. Kanu almost makes it three when he whips in a shot and forces a save from Westerveld. Full-time. Arsenal 2 - 0 Liverpool.

fields.headline: Britvic joins brands tango
fields.standfirst:
Breweries reshape: Tough times force slimmed lines tonic

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Soft drinks group Britvic could be up for grabs this week if a crucial regulatory decision goes in favour of its biggest shareholder, Bass, in a fresh step in the reshuffling of Britain's leisure brands.
fields.body:
Soft drinks group Britvic could be up for grabs this week if a crucial regulatory decision goes in favour of its biggest shareholder, Bass, in a fresh step in the reshuffling of Britain's leisure brands.

Bass is waiting to hear whether the sale of its brewing division can go ahead. If so, insiders say the company is likely to pull out of drinks manufacturing entirely.

It is reshaping in response to the plunging share prices in the hospitality industry which have also forced Whitbread to review long established restaurant brands such as Beefeater and Café Rouge.

Bass owns 50.1% of Britannia, a holding company which controls Britvic. The rest of the shares are held by rival drinks companies Allied Domecq and Whitbread - which have made no secret that they want to sell up. The soft drinks business, which makes Tango and R White's lemonade, is valued at around £400m.

Among the possible buyers are AG Barr, the Scottish manufacturer of Irn-Bru, and PepsiCo of the US. Both are thought to covet Britvic's household names - which include Robinson's Barley Water, at present being promoted by British tennis player Tim Henman.

Bass is not a hurried seller - Britvic made profits of £44m on sales of £543m last year. One drinks industry expert said: "It's a well run, smart operation, but it's not a core operation to Bass."

Britvic's complicated ownership structure has changed regularly - at one stage, the Australian brewer Castlemaine XXXX had a significant stake in the group.

Traditionally brewers have been keen to participate in soft drinks manufacturing in order to offer an all-round package of beverages to pubs and restaurants. However, the brewing sector has stagnated as drinkers shift towards wine and alcopops, and companies have moved towards spirits brands, hotels and pubs.

Whitbread and Bass are both in the middle of disposing of their breweries to Interbrew, the Belgian producer of Stella Artois.

The European commission has until Tuesday to decide whether to refer Interbrew's purchases back to trade secretary Stephen Byers.

Such a decision would put Bass in the clear: its deal is not dependent on British regulatory clearance.

Meanwhile Whitbread's embattled chief executive, David Thomas, is likely to approve big changes among the leisure group's poorly performing restaurants. Insiders brushed aside weekend speculation that the Beefeater brand was about to be axed, but admitted that it was likely to be radically altered, with different types of branches catering for different neighbourhoods.

The company's Café Rouge chain is likely to be slimmed down as part of a review bring carried out by restaurants boss Bill Shannon. Some outlets could be turned into Costa Coffee snack bars.

Mr Thomas is under pressure to reverse Whitbread's declining share price - speculation about his future has intensified over the last month, since the appointment of former Thomson Travel boss Charles Gurassa as a non-executive director.

Mr Gurassa is ambitious - he lost his job when Thomson was taken over, and he has been tipped as a future chief executive of Whitbread.

Analysts believe that Mr Thomas may soon choose to step down. He was widely criticised last summer, when the group's £2.7bn bid for Allied Domecq's pubs failed.

webTitle: Branson offers to hunt out bargains

fields.headline: Branson offers to hunt out bargains
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group will this morning attempt to capitalise on the groundswell of opinion against "rip-off Britain" with a digital shopping service that claims to offer consumers the best deal wherever and whenever they are buying goods.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group will this morning attempt to capitalise on the groundswell of opinion against "rip-off Britain" with a digital shopping service that claims to offer consumers the best deal wherever and whenever they are buying goods.

The Virgin Shopper, available through Virgin Mobile phones and virgin.com, will search for best prices and delivery times for thousands of items available on the web or in conventional shops.

Consumers will initially be able to search and compare items like DVDs, CDs televisions and fridge-freezers. Furniture, cosmetics and houses will be added soon.

Sir Richard said: "King consumer now has his crown with Virgin Shopper. It will completely revolutionise the way we shop. Why bother spending hours comparing prices and products when this service does it for you?"

The new initiative underlines but also tests Sir Richard's self-proclaimed position as a consumer champion. His companies tend to be described as offering a better than average service at cheaper prices - however, the Virgin Shopper could highlight areas where his goods are not the most competitive.

Virgin Megastores, Sir Richard's music chain, will not be available on the service but a Virgin Mobile spokesman said he was confident the stores would sign up soon.

fields.headline: Are you a teacher's pet?
fields.standfirst: Already left school? Think again, says Judi James, if a colleague thinks you are getting special treatment the old playground tactics can soon resurface in the office.
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Already left school? Think again, says Judi James, if a colleague thinks you are getting special treatment the old playground tactics can soon resurface in the office.
fields.body:
A faint whiff of sulphur hangs around the word favouritism. It implies pacts with the devil - selling your soul for promotion, or going for a pint with the boss every Friday, to ensure you get the desk next to the window when the office is re-organised.

"She only got it because she's the boss's favourite" can also be a cute get-out. When someone else gets the job you want or the piece of work you've been coveting, it's a hell of a lot easier to blame the system than to admit the better man/woman won.

The only thing worse than being on the suffering end of favouritism is to be wrongly accused yourself. At school, "Teacher's pet" meant isolation and resentment from the rest of the class . The only chance you had to get yourself back in the gang was by attempting to murder the teacher in question, possibly by tripwire on the stairs, but preferably by poison in the staff-room tea.

Favouritism isn't just a boss-employee problem, either. Anyone with an atom of control or clout in the workplace can be accused. Even tea ladies used to be charged with having favourites before coffee machines became the norm, as there was always one colleague who got given two choccie digestives for smiling nicely and flattering horribly, instead of the regulation stale Rich Tea.

Are you seething about jobs for the boys? Do all the promotions go to the ones who spend the rest of the year currying favour? Are you a victim of the Brown-nose brigade?

Coping with favouritism is difficult because resentment is a hard emotion to tackle. Sounding and acting bitter can scupper your work image, but why bother to be positive when the favourites get all the rewards anyway? Often you feel faced with two stark choices: Suck up big-time, or quit your job.

Before you do anything too radical, though, look at a few alternatives:
 No matter how much it pains you, you need to take very impartial view of the problem. Are you sure the charges of favouritism are valid? Or could they just be an excuse for your own lack of ability? If a colleague has been promoted over you it could be because they are better at the job. Put bitterness to one side and look at the facts. Are they more able? Is there any chance they got the job because they are more skilled? Harbouring resentment will do you no good if this is the case. Act grown-up and admit your failings so that you can improve before the next post is offered.


 Why do you think this person is a particular favourite? Again, be objective. Do you know they are fancied by/friends with the boss? Are you basing this assumption on rumour or fact?


 What have their rewards been? One woman was accused of being the boss's favourite because he always gave her the most work. Do you want to be the boss's extra-special slave? Think before you complain.


 If you believe the charge to be valid and intend to take steps about it, sit down and plan your strategy beforehand. This is going to be a tricky negotiation.

 Never use moaning to the rest of the team as part of your strategy. This is passive-aggressive behaviour. It gets you nowhere and only worsens the situation.


 Decide whether to speak to the boss in question or someone else, like his/her line manager or someone in human resources.
 Try to avoid the use of the word favouritism in this dialogue. It sounds emotive and is hard to prove. Take specific proof of times when you feel you have been unfairly treated.


 Be careful about using phrases like "We all think..." You may find the support you've been rallying from other colleagues evaporates quickly once an official complaint has been made.

And if you are accused?


 Keep cool. However unfair you think the accusations are you should avoid open conflict with the accusers. If you know you won that promotion through merit then you have nothing to worry about.


Don't bad-mouth the boss just to try to get on good terms with your colleagues again. This could get back to him/her and ruin the good relationship you have.


 Don't lose ground. One woman forged a good relationship with the new chief executive because he recognised her talent in a certain field. When a colleague warned her the others thought she was brown-nosing she started to avoid the new boss. She was then treated to the spectacle of her accusers sucking up to him big-time.


 Look relaxed and calm. Don't let them see the accusations are getting to you.


 Avoid confrontation in a bid to clear your name. I said that favouritism is a hard accusation to prove, but disproving it can be twice as difficult. Also - if your denial is done publicly - you may find you have alerted colleagues who weren't even aware of the idea in the first place. (A bit like denying you're having an affair with the entire local football team.)

fields.headline: Baton and bow
fields.standfirst:
ECO/Vengerov
Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.trailText:
ECO/Vengerov
Royal Albert Hall, London ****
fields.body:
Not content with being perhaps the world's greatest violinist at the age of 26, Maxim Vengerov is seeking new challenges. As well as the usual recital and concerto appearances, he's been performing in chamber groups, and has even swapped his Stradivarius for a baroque violin.

Now, with the assent of the English Chamber Orchestra, he's tried his hand at conducting. For the first half, he combined the roles of soloist and director in works by Bach and Schubert, and then a rarity - Mendelssohn's D minor Violin Concerto, an engaging work written when the composer was 13. Only in Mozart's Symphony No 29, the last item on an easy-listening programme, did he appear solely as conductor: a clean, poised performance, but lacking the electricity Vengerov generates with solo playing. He has an obvious rapport with his players and, conducting without a baton, shaped their playing nicely, but gave the impression that he was running with them rather than driving them on.

Then, alone on the platform after the interval, he held a packed Albert Hall spellbound: he's master of this trade. An arrangement of Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D minor, famous as an organ piece but possibly intended for solo violin, opened up an entirely new vista on the work. The thunder of the organ version was replaced by something more interesting, an intricate weave of melody and harmony. His encore was Paganini's Caprice No 24, his performance as dazzling as its composer, the original violinist-as-entertainer, could have wished. Vengerov's audience will be praying that he doesn't give up the day job - as a conductor, he's promising, but as a soloist he's a world-beater.

fields.headline: Standard stand-up
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Bill Bailey
Assembly Rooms ***
fields.body:
Bill Bailey
Assembly Rooms ***

"You're funny," someone shouts at Bill Bailey. "That's either deeply ironic," replies the comic, "or the worst heckle I've ever had." It could be both. Bailey is funny - at times very funny - but there is a familiarity to some of his jokes, and a bit of irony (or edge, or danger) would not go amiss.

He starts with a fine gag about his own hairy appearance: "I'm a victim of a teleportation incident. Peter Stringfellow got in the pod with me." But then he is off into standard stand-up: Australians, women and English tourists. It's a shame Bailey's reputation and slightly older audience allow him to be complacent, because off the cuff - brilliantly debunking author Tom Clancey - he is dynamite.

He frequently stops the gags to play musical instruments - he can barely keep his hands off his bongos and keyboards. Suddenly, the mullet makes sense: he is an exasperated heavy metal roadie, secretly dying to unleash rock operas about owls and toads. That he can do this in the guise of comedy must be wonderfully convenient. The "rearrangement" of the EastEnders theme is a hoot, but Bailey leaves you with a disturbing thought: no matter how great a man's talents, they risk untold damage by exposure to Marillion.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

webTitle: Rover stays in neutral over Proton

fields.headline: Rover stays in neutral over Proton
fields.trailText: Rover yesterday refused to be drawn on reports that it is in talks with the Malaysian car maker Proton over a proposed £1bn project to design and build a new model in Britain.
fields.body:
Rover yesterday refused to be drawn on reports that it is in talks with the Malaysian car maker Proton over a proposed £1bn project to design and build a new model in Britain.

The group has already confirmed that it has received an approach from another car manufacturer about possible cooperation over a new platform but has so far kept the identify of the company concerned under wraps.

Rover declined to comment on yesterday's report in the Observer that Proton, which owns sports car manufacturer Lotus had approached the British group, with a view to developing a new model which would be built in both the UK and Malaysia.

The UK group was formed after BMW dismembered the old Rover group and sold the Rover and MG marques and the Longbridge factory to a consortium headed by former Rover managing director John Towers earlier this year. The UK group is understood to have more immediate priorities than the choice of a partner to develop a new platform, and that a decision is unlikely to be taken until the spring.

Although its top of the range model, the Rover 75, is built on a comparatively new platform, its two other models, the 25 and the 45, are based on older Honda platforms which will need replacing by 2004. Given the time needed for development that would mean a decision will have to be taken early next year, according to industry insiders.

Developing new platforms is expensive - the Rover 75 platform, for example, is worth around £800m and Rover is perceived to need a partner to share the costs.

Proton is seen as a candidate because a link-up with Rover would bring it together with a European volume car maker. Companies with existing European plants - which includes almost all the world's leading manufacturers - are less likely to be interested because they already have as much if not more European capacity than they need.

Rover, bought from BMW for £10 three months ago, is in the process of moving the Rover 75 production line from Cowley - where BMW has retained ownership of the factory - to Longbridge. It is also working on expanding the model range.

Rover's ability to make its plans to continue volume car manufacturing at Longbridge have been treated with scepticism in some quarters, but yesterday Mr Towers hit back at the doubters.

He told the Observer: "I understand people worrying. It is classic to say if BMW could not do it, how can anyone else.

"There is always going to be nervousness. But we have got the best brains in the industry working on the cars and we are going to make them buzz."

fields.headline: Definitively devastating
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Schumann Chamber Music 2
Queen's Hall *****
fields.body:
Schumann Chamber Music 2
Queen's Hall *****

Peter Schreier's captivating performance of Schumann's Dichterliebe seemed to distil a lifetime's knowledge and love of one of the glories of the Leider repertoire into a mesmerising half-hour. The tenor must have sung Dichterliebe in innumerable programmes, but rarely can he have articulated a sense of the volcanic emotions lying just beneath the surface of Schumann's music with the vividness he achieved here.

Seldom, too, can he have found so symbiotic a partner as Andras Schiff. Schiff mirrored the subtlety of Schreier's rubato in the lyricism of Schumann's more reflective settings. And both were perfectly attuned to one another in the fresh impetuosity of the poet's love in the early songs of the cycle.

The programme - which also included the F major Piano Trio, The Fantasiestucke Op 73 for cello and piano, and more of the composer's songs - gave a fascinating insight into the music of Schumann's last years. In the funereal images of the last four songs, Schreier and Schiff were definitively devastating.

fields.headline: Snowy owls and desert sunsets
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Fool For Love
Dynamic Earth *
fields.body:
Fool For Love
Dynamic Earth *

Sam Shepherd's pressure-cooker of a play about destructive love is set in a single motel room for sound dramatic reasons. David Soul's attempt to open it up into a multi-media extravaganza is ill-advised - in more ways than one. Such were the appalling technical problems at the opening performance that the actors didn't stand a chance. But even on a good night, this would probably be a pop-video version of the play. This is a story about two people - half-brother and half-sister Eddie and May - who love each other so much they want to obliterate each other. It has nothing to do with romantic love and everything to do with the ravenous monster of desire. It is about the myths we make of our own lives in order to survive. Playing old Roberta Flack hits and showing us videos of snowy owls and desert sunsets doesn't begin to get to the heart of the matter.

With the anguished whispers of the technical crew providing an eerie chorus to the on-stage action, the actors more than had their work cut out. In other circumstances, Alexa Hamilton's May and Kristofer Soul's Eddie may indeed be capable of conveying the dangerous energy of caged animals. But the only danger I saw was that they wouldn't reach the end of the performance before the lights blacked out completely.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-530 3557.

fields.headline: Femme fatale
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Caroline Nin
Assembly Rooms ****
fields.body:
Caroline Nin
Assembly Rooms ****

Enitled Scarlet Stories, this entrancing hour with French singer Nin is a temporary passport to 30s Berlin. Backed by piano and double bass, Nin has obviously devoted her life to perfecting the Marlene Dietrich/ Marianne Faithfull/ streetwalking persona. And she gets right to the heart of the songs.

Love for Sale - accompanied by a film of late night tricks on Parisian walkways - is so romantically realistic I half expect the show to be raided by the vice squad. Nin is a classic femme fatale: she has perfected the art of erotically applying powder on stage, and during Marc Almond's The One and Only You, she slides up and down with her back against a pillar.

Behind the imagery lies warmth and mischievous humour. She jokes about her obsession with prostitutes, and dresses up as a PVC dominatrix to purr the sultry song Johnny on an understandably flushed bloke's lap. A cute touch, maybe, but this is a taste of intimacy with one of music's true dark angels.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

fields.headline: Living dinosaurs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
White Men with Weapons
Pleasance Over the Road 2 ***
fields.body:
White Men with Weapons
Pleasance Over the Road 2 ***

A kit bag of anecdotes from "living dinosaurs", Greig Coetzee's play looks at the changing position of the white South African military in the early 90s, as change made apartheid - the system they had shored up - a thing of the political past. Coetzee covers this uneasy ground with an intensity that comes from first-hand experience of what he calls South Africa's Vietnam. "The war's been cancelled," says one embittered man. "What we supposed to do?"

This question is posed by Coetzee playing a host of characters - new recruits, a gang member who has raped a woman, a gay soldier - each making their obsolescence plain through powerful stories. You won't like any of them, nor will you like the play's underlying message that anyone who ever benefited from apartheid, or who let it continue, has these brutal and brutalised characters to thank. There is dark humour too: the soldiers tie up their trouser bottoms because "you don't want communists to crawl up your pants". You'll be glad it's there in this otherwise bleak play.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.
