fields.headline: Poodle'd power
fields.standfirst:
Bon Jovi
Wembley Stadium ****
fields.trailText:
Bon Jovi
Wembley Stadium ****
fields.body:
Grotty Wembley Stadium is about to be replaced by a sexy new millennial edition, and the task of staging the old venue's last-ever gig fell, apparently randomly, to Bon Jovi. But as the show (sold out; who'd have thought the poodle-metal tycoons could still pull 60,000 customers a night?) unfolded, they seemed not so much a random choice as an apt way of saying goodbye to the era of monster stadium gigs and grown men in python leggings.

Jon Bon Jovi may have updated his image in the past few years, but the changes are only cosmetic. He's autumn/ winter 2000 in a Versace-ish gold suit, but underneath he's still J Bon Jovi of Arenarock Road, Tightpants, New Jersey. Sambora and leathery drummer Tico Torres are even less reconstructed. Together with the bassist and keyboardist who've grown into the label "the other two", they're a strutting, crowing bit of living history, hard rock as it was before it went on Prozac and began hanging out with rappers.

They're so assured that, after the opening cover of The Clash's London Calling, they dispense their most famous songs, Living on a Prayer and You Give Love a Bad Name. Anthemic doesn't begin to describe them. Wembley's walls only just contain the tornado created by the surge of frantic arms. It's a genuine rocktacular moment; nothing else approaches it. The rest of the long set is devoted to a lot of back catalogue and a little of the recent number one album, Crush.

Amazingly, Bon Jovi still get number ones, and the explanation is offered by the live performance. Not only do they explore their genre's not-very-extensive limits with just the right mix of maudlin ballads like Bed of Roses (cue lighters) and thunderous rockers, they meld them into a irresistible no-brainer stomp. Add Jon Bon's pert tush and you're looking at one formidable poodle-rock machine.

fields.headline: Wolves directors urged to reconsider
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries' senior executives will hold a crucial meeting today at which they are likely to reconsider a £470m takeover proposal from Botts & Co, the private equity firm.
fields.body:
Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries' senior executives will hold a crucial meeting today at which they are likely to reconsider a £470m takeover proposal from Botts & Co, the private equity firm.

Managing director David Thompson and his colleagues have come under pressure from shareholders to look again at the indicative offer, which they rejected on Friday.

Wolves, which brews traditional beers such as Banks's, Cameron and Pedigree, has struggled to swallow two big recent acquisitions - Mansfield Brewery and Marston, Thompson & Evershed.

The company's costs have spiralled out of control, partly due to a commitment to keep open all four of its breweries until at least 2001, despite the overcapacity in the industry.

If Wolves reiterates its rejection of Botts' 500p a share proposal, the private equity firm is likely to issue a direct appeal to shareholders asking them to support an offer. Botts has indicated that it is prepared to put more money on the table if it finds Wolves' finances encouraging. The brewer has so far refused to open up its books.

Botts has the backing of Royal Bank of Scotland and the US finance house Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette .

fields.headline: Creakingly obvious
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Keeping the Faith
Edinburgh film festival ***
fields.body:
Keeping the Faith
Edinburgh film festival ***

Stop me if you've heard this one, but there was a rabbi and a Catholic priest... The pitch for Keeping the Faith is creakingly obvious. What's odd is that Edward Norton, said to be one of Hollywood's tougher-minded young actors, should have chosen this amiably lightweight comedy as his directing debut.

Norton and Ben Stiller play childhood buddies who become a priest and a rabbi and get up to such ecumenical high-jinks as setting up an old folks' cross-faith karaoke centre. One day, the little girl they used to know - now a sassy exec, played by Jenna Elfman - comes to visit and turns their relationship into an awkward triangle.

Things pretty much conform to expectation, except that the script plays up the guys' irreverent hipness. We get a bit of friendly baseball, Norton staging a moody drunk fit, and Stiller working up his synagogue congregation by wheeling in a gospel choir. It may be generosity on Norton's part, but he gives Stiller all the best routines, especially in a running gag about his having to date congregants' eligible daughters. Norton himself plays it gentle, but comes across as whiny, oddly camp and altogether pallid.

The real reason to see the film is Elfman, from Ed-TV and sitcom Dharma and Greg. Something of an irritant in the past, she comes into her own here, with an abrasive, smart and sexy persona. Otherwise, Keeping the Faith is perfectly watchable - but 129 minutes for a light romantic comedy? That's a case of Hail Mary and enough already.

 At the ABC, Edinburgh (0131-623 8030), tonight.

fields.headline: Engaging alcoholic
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Owen O'Neill
Traverse ***
fields.body:
Owen O'Neill
Traverse ***

Where do old stand-up comics go? Owen O'Neill, the engaging Irish alcoholic whose searing, funny Off My Face was the toast of Edinburgh's past, has been into sitcom (he is the brains behind the new BBC series The Fitzes) and the kind of insubstantial theatre you wouldn't feed a family on.

It Was Henry Fonda's Fault starts beautifully in a flea pit cinema somewhere on the wrong side of the Irish border in the early 60s. For 45 minutes O'Neill didn't put a foot wrong, but then even he seemed to lose belief in the piece and fell back on some old trusty stand-up. There's a really good show in here somewhere, just like there's probably still two TV presenters inside Vanessa Feltz.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-228 1404.

webTitle: 'Up to 4 million at risk' from endowment trap

fields.headline: 'Up to 4 million at risk' from endowment trap
fields.trailText: Up to 4 million homeowners may be at risk of having their endowment mortgage policies pay out too little to repay their loans, according to figures circulating in the investment industry.
fields.body:
Up to 4 million homeowners may be at risk of having their endowment mortgage policies pay out too little to repay their loans, according to figures circulating in the investment industry.

About 40 per cent of the estimated 10 million people with endowments are said to be receiving letters from insurers warning of shortfalls.

The Association of British Insurers described the figures as 'speculative'. Nevertheless, Jane Whittles, the industry Ombudsman dealing with endowment complaints, is now so concerned that she is drafting guidance to companies about how to deal with compensation claims.

The aim is to force the firms to speed up the compensation procedure.

Whittle will tell companies the sort of cases in which they will be expected to pay com pensation, rather than pass them virtually automatically to her.

The Financial Ombudsman Service will ask firms to compare an endowment's performance with that of a repayment mortgage over the same period, and pay the customer the difference.

Several types of borrower are likely to be eligible, including those with no knowledge of the stock market, people sold an endowment close to retirement and purchasers of council homes under the right-to-buy scheme

However, compensation will not be automatic. A forecast shortfall alone will not be grounds for compensation unless the policyholder was misled.

Homeowners concerned about their endowments should continue to complain directly to whoever sold it.

webTitle: Discipline and control bring reward for Gloucestershire

fields.headline: Discipline and control bring reward for Gloucestershire
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 324 and 197
Essex 174 and 243
Gloucestershire won by 104 runs.
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 324 and 197

Essex 174 and 243

Gloucestershire won by 104 runs.
fields.body:
If you could play a Test match on the Castle Ground pitch it almost certainly wouldn't be over in two, three or even four days. Two years ago, Essex spent all the last day unavailingly trying to bowl out Leicestershire, with off-spinner Peter Such getting into the record books for the huge number of overs he delivered. Essex themselves were in that position yesterday, but their last six wickets got them only as far as half an hour after lunch.

It's true that the victory target of 348 was one the county game will regard as unlikely, but this is a good surface: well grassed and very dry, and consistent bounce. Batsmen who play strokes can race along, as Stuart Law did on Friday evening, when he and Paul Grayson took Essex to 123 before the second wicket fell. In retrospect, the express slip catch taken by Martyn Ball to end Law's innings may have been critical.

On that same pitch yesterday, Essex scored 102 - and captain Ronnie Irani got just 28 of them. The previous evening he had struck his first ball for four, but was to hit only two more yesterday in the course of another two and half hour's batting. He never looked as if he was in much trouble, but seemed unwilling to force the pace. Perhaps he reasoned that he would provide the backbone and others would play the shots.

Stephen Peters was starting to do that before he was splendidly taken low down at third slip by the 40-year-old Kim Barnett. Before long, 163 for five became 188 for seven, and the writing on the wall was writ large. The second of those wickets saw Barry Hyam looking a bit bemused as the bounce from off-spinner Jeremy Snape saw the ball brushing the bat's shoulder and floating to first slip.

Danny Law had different ideas. Facing Snape in the over before lunch, he jumped out to hoist the second ball for a very long six over long-on. After blocking the next ball, he repeated his six off the fourth ball.

After lunch, an on-side clip by Law found the safe hands, low down, of Chris Taylor at midwicket, and in another 20 minutes Gloucestershire had wrapped up a 104-run victory. They may have been last in the Second Division at the start of the day, but such is the congestion just above them that, come tomorrow, they're likely to be fewer than 10 points from third place.

Discipline was what their coach John Bracewell was looking for, and he got it. Gloucestershire batsmen had five partnerships worth 40 or more, Essex just one. The bowling of Ball, in particular, was splendidly controlled, and the catching outstanding throughout the match.

Control is an attribute that serves Gloucestershire so well in their one-day campaigns. So they were, in a sense, also brushing up for next Saturday and the NatWest final.

fields.headline: Gatting's boys under a cloud
fields.standfirst: 'It's an interesting job, being coach. But it's frustrating too, because you know how well these guys can play'. Mike Gatting, Middlesex's director of coaching, speaks to Kevin Mitchell
fields.trailText: 'It's an interesting job, being coach. But it's frustrating too, because you know how well these guys can play'. Mike Gatting, Middlesex's director of coaching, speaks to Kevin Mitchell.
fields.body:
'We had been through a gruelling two-and-a-half week training programme with our new fitness team, Chris St George, Al and Kerry, but this was broken up with a trip to our new sponsor Equitable Life's head office in Aylesbury to meet their staff, and then we had the pre-season dinner, which all went very well.'

It is comforting to note that, after years of dedicated scoffing, Mike Gatting has not lost sight of life's simple pleasures.

However, since the Middlesex director of coaching made the above observations on the club's website just before they left on a pre-season trip to South Africa, reality has kicked in like a bad pork pie.

Middlesex went into their latest match against Warwickshire on Thursday lying second last in division two of the championship, yet Gatting's combative spirit prevents him agreeing that this might be one of the most miserable seasons in the history of a club formed 136 years ago. Certainly it has been no Compton-Edrich golden summer of '47, or anything like the Brearley years of triumph: '76, '77, '80, '82 and '85.

But, says Gatting, 'It's the rain, really. Some people have managed to win games when they haven't had the rain; some people, like us, have got done by the rain a couple of times... plus, the fact is, yes, we've played poorly once or twice, I have to say that. The games we've looked like winning have been rained off, unfortunately; and the games where we've played badly, the weather's been good.'

There is not a professional athlete breathing who can rationalise a poor run of form like a county cricketer moving through an English summer under a permanent cloud. And Gatting has seen his share of rainy days.

He is one of the few England captains to go 10 Tests without a half-century, but he fought back, beating the bowlers if not the suits at HQ, who took the captaincy off him for nocturnal activities that had nothing to do with cricket and fined him for his candour in a ghosted book that said what he thought about the Pakistani umpire Shakoor Rana.

He was taken off Duncan Fletcher's England selection panel last season - although he still coaches the under 19 and A teams - and it was no pain for him to turn his attention to Middlesex, where he has played since turning up at Lord's from the Brondesbury club in north London as a brilliant teenager in 1975.

It is hard to recollect the buzz that surrounded his arrival that summer. His shape and style dictated he would always be characterised as pugnacious, and so he was in the course of 14 years as Middlesex captain, as well as 79 Tests and 98 one-day internationals for England. In one glorious patch, he led England to the Ashes in Australia and when he got back, was summoned to Buckingham Palace to receive an OBE - which only just nudged off the Gatting mantelpiece the bronze medal he got for ballroom dancing at the Neasden Ritz.

He was always an interesting cricketer, was Gatting: the first real working class captain of England, a part-time plumber, a lover of Beethoven, Holst and Elton John (their music, you understand), a good schoolboy goalkeeper who might have played for Watford... and then a beknighted leader of the unhappy rebel tour to South Africa, which he paid for with a five-year ban, rescinded in 1992. While banished, Gatting got immense pleasure from winning the county championship in 1990, and did it again in '93. Only Patsy Hendren scored more runs for the county. So what does this proud man of Middlesex make of their present mess?

'We've got a good squad. We're getting there and you've got to hold it together. But is the season a wash-out? I hope not. We're equal second in our national league and, yes, I know we're second from bottom in our division of the championship but there's only one win between second from bottom and second from top really. So we haven't written off the season at all.'

What the coach knows - but is entitled to keep to himself in the interests of team morale - is that the younger players have not given the senior pros the support their talent demands. 'It's an interesting job, being coach. But it's frustrating too, because you know how well some of these guys can play.'

Part of Gatting's remit as director of coaching is to keep an eye on schools talent, and there's always been a fair player base in prosperous Middlesex; tapping into it is not always simple.

'There's an age group between 14 and 16 where you lose a lot of players. We have to make them feel a bit more special, to not leave us. We have to make them come back for more, rather than going off and playing football.'

As his brother, Steve, did, of course. He was a good club cricketer and made the Middlesex 2nd XI but chose football, Arsenal then Southampton. There are a lot of Steves who drift away. And, while not every talented teenager abandons cricket before testing his potential properly, the crop is thin.

At Middlesex this season, only Andy Strauss, 23, among the young batsmen has contributed much (735 championship runs at 36.75) behind Mark Ramprakash (821 at 58.64) and their charismatic Australian captain, Justin Langer (914 at 45.70). Owais Shah, 21, of whom so much has been expected in his short career, is averaging in the low twenties and elsewhere the team are living on promise.

With the ball it is a similar story. Angus Fraser, whose bones must soon be examined for traces of steel, rumbles on, as does the world's oldest teenager, Phil Tufnell, and his left index finger might yet spin him back into the England touring squad. The Cat has taken 52 wickets at 21 apiece, steady as a slow-burning fag.

Gatting, meanwhile, lives for tomorrow. 'There's a lad who's going to play probably the rest of the summer now, called Ed Joyce. He could do very, very well. He's from Ireland, played for them quite a bit (33 internationals), he's 22 and is going to be full-time when he's got the finals of his exams out of the way. We'd played over in Ireland two or three times and people there said we should keep an eye on him. So he came over and played a couple of games and he looks slightly different to the rest. Bats left-handed.'

Who can be sure: maybe Joyce can make headlines like, 'Mystery Irishman saves Middlesex'. It could hardly be worse. Gatting is more aware than most of how hard it is to generate interest in cricket with so many distractions.

'England have started doing a little bit better now. There was the win at Lord's, winning the triangular tournament as well has focussed people's eyes on cricket. But just as England start to do well, the football season starts, and all of a sudden the good stuff that's happening to cricket is put on the inside pages.'

fields.headline: System benefits Caddick
fields.standfirst: The secret of Test success lies in the new ECB rules but there are still problems to iron out
fields.trailText: It was almost perfect: England, potent and purposeful, stormed to an innings victory over the West Indies, their first in 34 years and that elusive series win against them was in sight. The nation, apart from ticketholders for Saturday and Sunday, rejoiced.
fields.body:
It was almost perfect: England, potent and purposeful, stormed to an innings victory over the West Indies, their first in 34 years and that elusive series win against them was in sight. The nation, apart from ticketholders for Saturday and Sunday, rejoiced.

There may also have been one or two quiet reservations in the offices of the county grounds of England. There they might be calculating the loss of revenue from another truncated Test match. For the third time this summer at least half a million pounds has gone begging; the optimists tell us that this might all be recouped as potential sponsors, contemplating taking the place of Cornhill Insurance, are seduced by the prospect of a successful England side.

Moreover those counties anxious to have their England stars in their side to ensure promotion or the avoidance of relegation received another setback. For this victory seemed to vindicate the introduction of centrally contracted players and their reduced work load.

I should declare an interest here. As a Somerset committee man I recognise that it is vital to have Andrew Caddick - and Marcus Trescothick - in the county team to ensure success. It so happened that on Friday I was chatting to the fourth selector, Geoff Miller, when Caddick, still wicketless in the game, was shifted to the Rugby Stand End. As is my wont in this sort of company I murmured that 'Caddick has looked a bit rusty in this match'. Whereupon he bowled that over: four wickets in the space of seven deliveries (there was a no-ball). Miller did not feel it necessary to respond.

The advent of central contracts has changed the lifestyle of Caddick more than any other of the England cricketers. There has always been the notion, clung to by Somerset committee men, that he is the type of cricketer who thrives on bowling. Last summer, when he made a suc cessful return to the England side, he bowled 763 first class overs. So far this year he has bowled 290. He may end the season having delivered less than 350. And after Friday it is tricky to argue that his potency has been reduced.

If England keep winning we cannot argue with a new system, which requires our top players to develop a new discipline. In the wake of another fine England performance Duncan Fletcher could whisk his charges off to the Algarve for a week in the middle of August and no one could complain too much. The players are learning to prepare themselves for key games without playing domestic cricket.

This new discipline should help them on tour. Away from home England cricketers have often felt starved of cricket. Denied the rhythm of the English county season the batsmen especially have often felt short of time in the middle, while the bowlers have had to sharpen their game in the nets, not their natural habitat. They are now learning to do this in England while the risk of injury from overbowling in county cricket has been reduced.

However the new system is not perfect. It is still important to retain the integrity of domestic cricket. Duncan Fletcher has announced that those players selected for both Test and one day cricket on the winter tours will not be allowed to play for their counties as the season in its new format, with all the anticipated thrills of promotion and relegation, reaches its climax. This is highly unsatisfactory.

The ECB claim that this is a one-off situation, that the trip to Nairobi for the mini World Cup - the players leave on September 29 - is unlikely to be repeated. It is imperative that they ensure that this really is the case. In the future they have to insist that England should not have any winter commitments until the end of October. In this way the contracted players would be able to participate in the finale to the English county season season, thereby raising the profile of a domestic game, which is in danger of being swamped by international cricket.

There have been other teething problems. The elevation of Chris Schofield to central contract status was always going to be a mistake and that has now been acknowledged. In hindsight the contracts given to Dean Headley and Mark Ramprakash were also a waste.

However on balance the selectors have to be held in unusually high esteem at the moment. Their surprising decision to offer Craig White a contract has been justified. This gave a diffident man new faith in himself. They have also plucked out two batsmen for the future, Michael Vaughan and Marcus Trescothick, and their reading of the Headingley pitch, which resulted in the recall of Graeme Hick at number seven, was spot on.

Jimmy Adams in a dignified press conference after a desolate West Indian performance refused to complain about the pitch and it was loyally defended by Darren Gough.

But it was inadequate for Test cricket, a fact which Nasser Hussain was realistic enough to concede. It is absurd that Yorkshire should proudly tell us of a £10million revamp of Headingley, incorporating plush new stands when the most fundamental element of any cricket arena - the square - remains sub-standard. Most Test matches should last five days; this summer four of the six have yet to make it to Monday, which should temper some of the euphoria of an English victory at the ECB.

We anticipate something better at the Oval, the venue for the final Test of the summer. There the ball has turned consistently this summer, a fact that will be the only source of agonising for the England selectors in the next week. They will be reluctant to change this side since it is mighty difficult to work out who should be omitted to make way for a spinner. They can't leave out their most run-shy batsman, Hussain, since he's the captain and any suggestions along that line will only come from mischievous hacks. After Headingley they will be reluctant to leave out Hick.

Given Robert Croft's lack of success on a slow turner at Old Trafford, they will only want to play a spinner if they are convinced that the ball will turn prodigiously. Rather than go for an out and out specialist like the ageing Phil Tufnell or Peter Such they may consider Ashley Giles for his all-round skills. They would rather that the Oval produced a benign non-turner.

However these problems are pinpricks compared to those facing the West Indies. Their support bowlers have had their confidence shredded; their batting line-up can collapse as rapidly as any England side in recent history. Viv Richards, his pride hurt, spoke on Friday of his attempts to persuade Ambrose and Walsh to keep going for their daunting trip to Australia this winter just to keep the ship afloat. Jimmy Adams despaired of his side's inconsistency: 'Being able to spark now and again won't cut at this level.'

How often have we heard England captains express the same sentiments in recent times. The wheel might just be turning.

webTitle: Warwickshire must be wary of quirky Barnett

fields.headline: Warwickshire must be wary of quirky Barnett
fields.trailText: Even before he bowled for the first time to Kim Barnett, Glenn McGrath should have known what to expect. The world's number one, a man not short of a word or two, was silent as he stood for some time at the start of his run, apparently unable to comprehend what he saw.
fields.body:
Even before he bowled for the first time to Kim Barnett, Glenn McGrath should have known what to expect. The world's number one, a man not short of a word or two, was silent as he stood for some time at the start of his run, apparently unable to comprehend what he saw.

The batsman was standing outside leg stump, showing him all three stumps. Was it a wind up? The famous McGrath head-shaking very nearly started before he bowled the ball.

Warwickshire's bowlers at Lord's next Saturday will not be so bemused, for Barnett has been employing his strange method for some time in the county game. The likes of Allan Donald and Ed Giddins - assuming they are fit - may even try to ignore the progressive steps that Barnett takes across his crease, erase the thought that they are bowling at a moving target, and instead concentrate instead on bowling to a batsman who, like most others, is in front of his middle and off stumps as he is playing the ball.

Since Warwickshire's coach is Bob Woolmer, mind games as well as tactics may prove the key to a fascinating 2000 NatWest final. Certainly Barnett, now in his fifth consecutive final, has got the innings well launched in all of his previous four appearances. In the 1998 NatWest, with Derbyshire, the Barnett-Slater stand was 70 - too bad that a Lancashire torpedo hit Derbyshire after that. In last year's two victories for Gloucestershire, Barnett hit 28 and 49 in stands worth 66 and 125. Two months ago in the B&H it was 39 in a stand of 80.

So the lesson is: don't mistake eccentricity for a weak point. There was a technical reason, says Barnett, for the method he adopted many years ago. 'A few old pros said I couldn't get away with the way I was playing. I was too leg-side of the ball and too back-foot. So I had to change. And I changed immediately.'

It wasn't in his mind to unsettle bowlers, but that is now regarded as an asset by a Gloucestershire management strong on fresh, imaginative thinking.

Indeed, the 40-year-old Barnett is probably out-thinking the bowlers. He does his homework, he says, and takes a lot of thought into games. 'I try different things. I think that's the essence of batting, really. You've got to take into account different opponents. I would think that every innings I do a few things differently.'

This is an attitude which very much fits with that of coach John Bracewell, who says: 'A good player should be thinking, "How many shots can I play on this wicket, in these conditions, against this bowler?" That's why we got Kim. He's a tactical player, not a technical player. There's not enough of them.'

Actually, Gloucestershire do have a few more. Like Ian Harvey, the Australian and Jack Russell, whose batting style is almost as odd as Barnett's.

Then there's the fielding. Under Bracewell, Gloucestershire have raised it to a new level, with fielders mentally geared to attacking the batsman rather than reacting to him. 'I've had to work hard to keep up with these boys,' says Barnett, 'even if they do have to hide me to some degree. It's the best fielding side I've ever seen. Against Lancashire in the semi-final there was a half-hour that made you think of the Harlem Globetrotters.'

'I've had to work hard to keep up with these boys,' says Barnett, 'even if they do have to hide me to some degree. It's the best fielding side I've ever seen. fields.headline: Courageous leadership lifts England
fields.trailText: How bad can our Test pitches get? At Edgbaston and Lord's, the matches all over in three days: Headingley well short of two. As Ian Bishop said on TV on Friday, it's hard to bowl a straight ball on this pitch. These pitches sort the sheep from the goats when it comes to batting - as well as those blessed with good fortune and those not. One Test is whether, after facing three or four balls that move sharply or lift, a batsman has the confidence and poise to remain positive and balanced for the rare loose one.
fields.body:
How bad can our Test pitches get? At Edgbaston and Lord's, the matches all over in three days: Headingley well short of two. As Ian Bishop said on TV on Friday, it's hard to bowl a straight ball on this pitch. These pitches sort the sheep from the goats when it comes to batting - as well as those blessed with good fortune and those not. One Test is whether, after facing three or four balls that move sharply or lift, a batsman has the confidence and poise to remain positive and balanced for the rare loose one.

For England, Thorpe and Vaughan in particular showed this quality here at Headingley, Atherton and Trescothick earlier in the year; for West Indies only Sarwan managed it here. To see just two batsmen glorying in their art was, over the series of Tests, as rare a sighting as seeing the lesser spotted woodpecker: the cricket watcher needed to be at Old Trafford to be reminded of this aspect of the game by Lara's and Stewart's masterly innings.

At Headingley the cricket has been absorbing, of course, especially for the home crowd. But it is not good enough. The dice are loaded too heavily against the batsman. Fast bowlers are flattered, slow ones surplus to requirements. Top-class batsmen can be reduced to missing the ball by two bats' width. And what about the thousands who booked up for their Saturday at the Test?

West Indies lost this game, like the one at Lord's, primarily in one department - in their support bowling. Every England innings of the series has had two phases; the first when it looked near-impossible to score a run, and survival was precarious; the second when any two of King, Rose and McLean were on.

Now Bishop's dictum had a different implication - it suddenly became hard to imagine a ball being straight not in the sense of being undeviating, but in being bowled on the stumps. On Friday, for the first time in my cricketing life, I felt sorry for a West Indies fast bowler. Reon King is clearly a bowler of potential, regularly managing 88-90 mph, with a low, skiddy outswing shape. Yet on a pitch on which accuracy was at a premium, he bowled a series of deliveries that were embarrassingly wide. He kept his dignity, fielded with dash while all around his team were falling to pieces, yet inside he must have felt like a small boy shamed in front of the whole school.

England by contrast look a proper team, without glaring weaknesses. Gough seems back to his old best, or better. He uses his brain now, as well as his body. He has long been able to swing the new ball out and the old one in, at a slippery pace.

At times, however, he has in the past felt the onus of a weak attack too much on his shoulders, ending up ragged as a result of trying to do other people's jobs as well as his own.

Now he is properly supported, and can do his own thing, knowing that others will play their proper parts. England have at present a full range of quickish bowlers. Caddick for instance is a bowler who comes down from a height, with steeper bounce, while Gough's bounce is skimmy. While Gough has variety, Caddick at his best is relentless. Like Gough, Cork has grown cannier with age, giving away fewer runs on occasions when the ball doesn't swing; he is slower than Gough, and swings the ball more. And White has been the bowling find of the summer, bowling with speed and hostility whether in one-day matches or Tests.

What's more, the catching has been excellent, especially with Hick in the side. With Thorpe back alongside him the slip cordon looks as menacing and confident as an Australian one.

What also impresses me is the thinking that has gone into selection and tactics. Before the event I applauded both the selection for this Test match - seven batsmen and four bowlers, and the use of a nightwatchman, despite the fact that this meant Hick going in at number eight. Even Caddick's 20 minutes at the crease on Friday morning served the purpose of limiting the time that Hick would have to face the combined A-team of Ambrose and Walsh.

I applauded too the selection of Thorpe for the last Test and this: his innings here was even classier than Vaughan's, since it was made against the two great bowlers with their tails up and a new ball in their hands. Hussain himself played a vital part; his 22, made when out of form and up against it, exuded sheer determination and pluck. Had either gone early England could have had a first innings deficit rather than the comfortable lead.

I could mention other decisions that were taken within the match on the basis of feel for the situation rather than by rote. Here are two. One was Hussain's giving White so many overs in the first innings. It can take courage to believe your eyes as captain, and recognise the superiority, on his day, of someone who has generally been lower in the pecking order.

I remember how reluctant I was, on a tour of Australia, to give full credence to the fact that Hendrick, earmarked as a likely reserve, was actually performing as our best bowler. It even took a casual comment from one of our state opponents to convince me. This year someone has spotted White's qualities and given him the confidence to express himself.

My other example was the use of Caddick in the second innings. When Gough was taken off after his devastating spell, the routine decision, after the first innings, would have been to give the ball to White. Instead Caddick was brought on to bowl up the hill for the first time in the match. Here Hussain acknowledged, perhaps, both that Caddick was still likely to swing the ball out, and that he might bang the ball in to the pitch harder, from his height, when running up the hill.

One final comment. In this match England have made use off all their assets - including the less glamorous one of harrying and scuttling their opponents between the wickets. During the crucial period when England surged from 96-5 to 272 all out, Caddick, Hick, Cork and above all, cool-head Vaughan used this ploy first to gain momentum and in the end to rattle the West Indies in the field. This was the cricket of a team willing to hustle and fight for each other.

Such a team suggests good leadership, both on and off the field. And in his brief post-match interviews, following the modest Hussain, Duncan Fletcher's taciturn bluntness was massively reassuring.

webTitle: A sound way to judge catches?

fields.headline: A sound way to judge catches?
fields.trailText: Norman Harris's Inside Edge column.
fields.body:
The snickometer has always been portrayed as a novelty rather than categoric proof of a snick or a miss. For one thing, the sound waves created by contact with bat edge and pad need skilled interpretation, and one may come very close to the other.

But there have been a number of episodes in which the conclusion of the Snicko has defied all other evidence - including that of the batsman himself. And last Monday's NatWest semi-final at Bristol featured a particularly uneven performance by the funny sound waves.

When Gloucestershire's Kim Barnett slashed at a wide ball in the first over, all the Lancashire players seemed sure he had got a thin top edge - not given by the umpire, who instead signalled a wide. Commentators studying the replay came to the same conclusion as unhappy Lancashire. But the Snicko's reading, when it arrived, surprisingly showed no contact.

Later in the day the data - video matched to sound - was run again. This time it registered a clearcut snick, and that is what Channel 4 showed in their highlights programme. Invited to comment, a spokesman could say only: 'We've always said [the Snickometer] isn't an exact science.' But surely it has to be, if there is to be any point in it?

In recent years, Warwickshire have had an over-50s team who were the envy of all their opponents in this hotly contested annual competition. The senior Bears boasted Alan Oakman, John Jameson and Eddie Hemmings, all former England players, and also the little master of Pakistan and Northamptonshire, Mushtaq Mohammad.

Now, only Mushy remains. The durable Oakman has finally retired at 70. And it hasn't been possible to recruit Dennis Amiss, now Edgbaston's chief executive. But the biggest blow for the Warwickshire over-50s is a failure to locate Alvin Kallicharran when the former West Indies left-hander reached the qualifying age last year.

To the chagrin of the Bears, Kalli has emerged this year in Middlesex colours - and is starring for them. His four innings have produced two centuries, a 70 and, most recently, 63. Only a controversial run-out decision ended that innings, but it didn't stop Middlesex from qualifying for the quarter-finals. Kalli and co play Devon today.

*****

Indifferent light may still terrify professional cricketers, but these days they're not half so bothered by slipping and sliding. As the new laws of cricket boldly state: 'Merely because the grass and the ball are wet and slippery does not warrant the conditions being considered unreasonable or dangerous.'

The new attitude was dramatically illustrated at Old Trafford last week when an abbreviated day-night match was played with surface water in one corner - water into which Kent's Martin Saggers aquaplaned for several metres with an attempted boundary save.

It is said that even in the championship captains and umpires will agree to play if outfield puddles are at least 35 metres from the stumps.

*****

Warwickshire's enthusiasm for floodlit matches may be waning.

Following modest attendances of around 4,000 - much the same as on Sundays - and criticism of the strength of the temporary lighting, they've now had their application for permanent lights turned down. Birmingham's chief planning officer cites light spillage, noise and traffic.

Warwickshire must now decide whether to appeal to the High Court, continue with costly hiring of lights - or give up on night cricket.

webTitle: Portugal: the passion and melancholy of Lisbon's fado festival

fields.headline: Happy to be sad
fields.standfirst: Max Wooldridge  on the passion and melancholy of Lisbon's fado festival
fields.trailText: The 'fadista' stands firm with her eyes closed and head thrown back. Her hair is bundled into a massive bunch behind her. Her hands are clasped across her chest and the fingers have formed an external rib cage. Two guitarists, one with a pear-shaped soundboard, establish a tempo. They are dressed in perfectly pressed suits. But it's not fado until the proud, slightly plump lady sings.
fields.body:
The 'fadista' stands firm with her eyes closed and head thrown back. Her hair is bundled into a massive bunch behind her. Her hands are clasped across her chest and the fingers have formed an external rib cage. Two guitarists, one with a pear-shaped soundboard, establish a tempo. They are dressed in perfectly pressed suits. But it's not fado until the proud, slightly plump lady sings.

Every muscle in her neck moves as she lets rip. Her haunting voice is on the melancholy side of flamenco. Think Edith Piaf on downers and you're halfway there. A heavy earnestness and respectful silence fill the air. If I make a noise, I think I'm going to be thrown out. Grin and I will be lynched. Certainly a smile from any of the musicians is likely to break a clause in their contract. Like poets, fado singers use few words to express a lot of emotion. Performances are short because it's so intense. There's such deep feeling that after a few songs she is sweating.

Fado is taken so seriously because you've tapped into the deep expression of the Portuguese soul. You're in the presence of absence, where an innate melancholy reigns. These are songs born in the hearts of homesick sailors adrift on uncharted seas. From the time when ships sailed abroad and didn't come back. It's a longing for something that's gone and this sadness keeps them happy.

When Portugal's greatest fadista, Amalia Rodrigues, died in October 1999, there was an enormous outpouring of public grief and three days' national mourning. 'I never cry, but I cried the day Amalia died,' says my waiter, Luis. 'She was our Princess Diana. People liked her because she was natural, she didn't pretend to be important. She never lost her common touch.'

Amalia would certainly approve of Lisbon's latest festival, a week of nightly concerts and exhibitions celebrating fado. And, like the great Portuguese explorers, the festival will cross the oceans and explore fado's links with similar musical forms, such as the mornas from the Cape Verde Islands, the tango of Buenos Aires, Cajun music from New Orleans, flamenco from Andalucia and rembetika, the Greek blues born in the ports of Piraeus and Salonika at the start of the twentieth century.

Like fado, all these musical styles sprang from the poorest levels of society to become cultural emblems of their countries. Bittersweet anthems of longing that draw inspiration from common themes of fate, love and destiny. The music reflects a difficult, hard and often sad life. Life has always revolved around the sea in Lisbon. The celebrated Portuguese poet, Fernando Pessoa, wrote that every pier is a longing of stone. He was right. Ports breed sadness, but also cultural interchanges.

The origins of fado are hotly contested. Some swear it was born of Gypsies or Arabs, while others theorise it may have been the musical longings of African slaves, freighted to Brazil. It is the small hours before I finally emerge from the fado house. The narrow, cobbled streets of the Bairro Alto (Upper Quarter) are now amok with hundreds of good-natured young Lisboetas . Virtually every doorway is some kind of bar. Late nights are an essential part of Lisbon, but you pay a price.

In the morning, weary from lack of sleep, I take the Edwardian tramline to the hilly, mediaeval streets of Alfama, Lisbon's Moorish quarter. Fado emerged from these streets in the eighteen-thirties among people in poorly paid jobs often connected with the sea. Originally the music was associated with prostitution and Bohemian life.Only in the late nineteenth century did fado enter aristocratic circles.

You sense that Alfama is a close community that looks out for its own. But what else would you expect from what is in essence a fishing community? You meet the eyes of proud, old men in flat caps and cardigans, but their half-smiles hint at a terrible foreboding. Dignified old ladies with kind faces watch from their balconies. Every face tells a story, of personal sorrows, of a longing for something out of reach.

At the foot of Alfama, the House of Fado and Portuguese Guitar documents the history and roots of Lisbon's own music. Not bad for a former city water supply pumping station.

In a café, elderly men crowd around a flimsy table. They slam playing cards down with such ferocity you think the table will collapse. Behind the counter a barman looks on quietly, torn between the action and the pages of a novel. Their game of cards is not quite as intense as last night's fado, but it is still early.

Fact file

Lisbon's next fado festival is from 3-11 February 2001. The House of Fado and Portuguese Guitar is at 1 Largo do Chafariz de Dentro, Alfama, Lisbon (10am-5pm daily, but closed Tuesdays).

Flights: TAP Air Portugal (0845 601 0932) and British Airways (0845 77 333 77) fly to Lisbon at festival time for £159.20. Go (www.go-fly.com) offers a £103 return, if booked now.

Accommodation: The Portuguese Tourist Board is on 0900 1600370 or 0207 494 1441. Website: www.atl-turismolisboa.pt

webTitle: St Joseph, Missouri, and the legend of Jesse James

fields.headline: In search of Jesse
fields.standfirst: Tom Adair rides into St Jo, a town that proudly safeguards the legend   of Jesse James, shot in the back by a turncoat
fields.trailText: Jesse James and Roy Rogers were my big-time boyhood heroes. 'One mean hombre,' drawled our teacher - meaning Jesse had a gift for robbing banks, plus a killer instinct, and was quick on the draw. And he had a gang. The things I craved as an only child. I longed to be dangerous. I imagined him stinking of horse, swilling whisky, chewing cheroots. So, when I finally hit St Joseph in north-west Missouri where Jesse had lived, I wanted a sense of the place, to hear the echo of his hoofbeats.
fields.body:
Jesse James and Roy Rogers were my big-time boyhood heroes. 'One mean hombre,' drawled our teacher - meaning Jesse had a gift for robbing banks, plus a killer instinct, and was quick on the draw. And he had a gang. The things I craved as an only child. I longed to be dangerous. I imagined him stinking of horse, swilling whisky, chewing cheroots. So, when I finally hit St Joseph in north-west Missouri where Jesse had lived, I wanted a sense of the place, to hear the echo of his hoofbeats.

St Joseph is Missouri's cowboy capital (pop: 72,000). It sees its future linked inextricably to the past. A tour of its 13 museums - from the Glore Psychiatric Museum, to the Patee House emporium, to the James House (where Jesse bit the dirt), to the Pony Express Museum and Stables - will take longer than it took to try Jesse's killer, Robert Ford, and get a conviction. Then again, my theory that Jesse was killed by his mother - based entirely on the facts - was not something that went down well on the streets. Whenever I mentioned it, looks suggested that I had escaped from a psychiatric wing.

The night I arrived, a state trooper was shot by a fugitive raiding a shop - an aberration as it turned out, for St Jo is a tidy town, amid rolling fields, set by the banks of the River Missouri, a place of fine mansions and lawns. It oozes prosperity. It boasts guys who tip their stetsons to womenfolk. To find it on the map, sketch diagonals from America's opposite corners. They'll cross at St Jo, the country's heartland, bang, slap, middle. Still, the people here call it the West. It retains that frontier feel, the sense of how it was when cowmen spread from the East and reached the boundary of the Missouri and everything else was the Great Beyond.

'I don't have a problem with Jesse James,' says Gary Chilcote, curator-director of the Patee House. 'He helps support this place. Done more good since he died than ever he did when alive.' The Patee House was the biggest hotel in town in 1860 when the pioneer Pony Express sent riders high-tailing towards Sacramento, 2,000 miles west, with government contracts locked in their saddlebags.

Down at the stables they'll show you the posters: 'Wanted. Young skinny wiry fellows not over 18. Must be expert riders, willing to risk death daily. Orphans preferred.' When you gaze at the murder weapons collection at the Patee House, you can guess that orphans were not in short supply around St Jo. Buffalo Bill was one of the Pony Express's couriers out of St Joseph in his early teens, earning $25 a week, a bonanza wage for the risk of being ambushed by Paiute Indians.

The Pony Express lasted 18 months before the telegraph usurped it. In the stables they've resurrected it in spirit. I stood in a bunkhouse and smelled its smallness, its vulnerability to attack, the shadow of history in the cobwebby dark of its corners. In the Patee House, St Joseph's eventful past is spotlit in unexpected ways (they exhibit the cowcatcher locomotive out of Hannibal to St Jo, that chuntered west across the plains at the mercy of outlaws). Chilcote shows me upstairs to the polished Buffalo Saloon, where the following week the Jesse James Ball was to be held, the ladies in gingham finery, the men in waistcoats, stetsons, and high-heeled cowboy boots, without spurs.

'Spurs is banned since the time they shredded the women's dresses,' Chilcote says, with a tinge of regret. He shows me the white-clapboard home outside, in the shadow of the Patee House: the abode of Jesse James. The bullet hole in the living-room has been there since 3 April 1882, when Jesse was shot by one of his gang, having turned his back to straighten a picture on the wall. 'God Bless This Home, ' it reads, still off kilter.

Over lunch at the Sunset Grill, I gaze across the wide Missouri and come to terms with Jesse's soft-boiled, middle-class, educated nature. His father, I've learnt, was a Baptist minister, his mother Zerelda a harridan, who brought her boys up strictly, to keep themselves tidy. Those I've talked to around St Joseph either eulogise Jesse or think him a skunk who shot 16 men, but even they seem queasy that Jesse was killed with his back turned. Next day I drive to the farm at Kearney, where Jesse grew up. Here Zerelda ruled the roost. The boys learnt to shoot and lay a table.

I read the inscription on Jesse's grave: 'Murdered by a traitor and a coward whose name is not worthy to appear here.' Zerelda wrote those words, as surely as Jesse was trained by her to straighten crooked pictures. Had Zerelda unwittingly led him to his death? 'Never thought of that,' says Phil Stewart, the guide. 'I blame the fact that he was lazy. Didn't wanna earn a living. What d'you think?' What I am thinking, to my surprise, is: whatever happened to Roy Rogers? But I look at Phil in silence, then I answer: 'Guess you're right.'

 Tom Adair travelled as a guest of the Missouri Division of Tourism and Continental Airlines. Reservations: 0800 776464) .For a free information pack on Missouri, contact Cellet Travel Services on 01564 794999

fields.headline: Holiday memories by Quentin Blake
fields.trailText: When I was a child you couldn't really go abroad because abroad was full of Nazis. Some of my first holidays were being evacuated. Once was to a village in Devon called Beer. There were no tourists and obviously I wasn't very happy because I was away from home. But you could walk along the beach and collect, on a pointed stick, all the dabs and plaice that the fishermen threw out. You would pay them sixpence. I think that started a lifelong interest in eating fish - I still hang around fish shops.
fields.body:
When I was a child you couldn't really go abroad because abroad was full of Nazis. Some of my first holidays were being evacuated. Once was to a village in Devon called Beer. There were no tourists and obviously I wasn't very happy because I was away from home. But you could walk along the beach and collect, on a pointed stick, all the dabs and plaice that the fishermen threw out. You would pay them sixpence. I think that started a lifelong interest in eating fish - I still hang around fish shops.

My first real holiday was when I was at secondary school. We went camping on the edge of Romney Marsh and I have loved marshes ever since: the smell of the mud, the cries of the birds and the boats. You feel as if you are looking at an infinite horizon.

I did National Service from 1951 to 1953 and afterwards I went to Bordeaux with a friend, and spent my first night in Paris on the way down. That was my first time abroad. I remember hiring bicycles in Bordeaux. The bicycles were hanging up in the shop and the man went along them, feeling their tyres as if to see if they were ripe.

Bordeaux was cobbled, so it was uncomfortable cycling in the town, but outside Bordeaux it was wonderful going through pine forests, discovering French food and old churches with Romanesque engraving. Now I regularly go to France, partly to holiday but also to give talks in schools. I do these in French as best I can, but if I am at a loss for words I draw.

 Quentin Blake: author, illustrator and Childrens' Laureate. 'Quentin Blake's Words and Pictures' is published on 26 September

webTitle: The Almenara Hotel, Spain: a top concierge reveals all

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.trailText:
The Almenara Hotel, Spain
Ricardo Andrés Ballester, head concierge
fields.body:
The Almenara Hotel, Spain
Ricardo Andrés Ballester, head concierge

What is the best thing about the Almenara?
We have amazing views across the Andalusian countryside and the Mediterranean. On a clear day you can see Africa. However, the best thing is the Golf Central Reservation System which allows guests to book tee times at six courses in Sotogrande, including Valderrama, considered one of the best in Europe.

Doesn't Sotogrande also host polo's Gold Cup?
Yes, polo has been played in Sotogrande for many years and is the main reason people come here in August. Seville, Jerez and the Alhambra Palace are easily accessible, as are Ceuta and Tangier in Morocco by ferry.

webTitle: Kids' Escape: theatre workshops and diving lessons

fields.headline: It's showtime
fields.trailText: Fun things for kids to do during the summer holidays
fields.body:
London's West End theatres will teem with children during Kids' Week, from Friday until 1 September. The annual scheme, during the last week of the summer holidays, allows children free theatre tickets, free meals in some restaurants and free entrance to theatre workshops.

During Kids' Week a paying adult is entitled to an extra free child theatre ticket. Participating shows include A Midsummer Night's Dream, Cats, Chicago, The Pirates of Penzance and Starlight Express.

However, parents and children can take part in a range of workshops free of charge. For example: take dance lessons from The King and I dancers (29 August), or the cast of Chicago (30 August); join the Cats' Kids' Club (26 August); or run away with the circus (Hard Times, 26 August). For an extra treat restaurants, including Planet Hollywood and the Hard Rock Cafe, are offering discounts if you present the Kids' Week leaflet.

The offers are subject to availability and you should book in advance on the Ticketmaster Kids' Week hotline: 020 7413 1431. For full details call the Kids' Week Information Line on 08700 732 000 or visit www.kidsweek.co.uk

How to go in at the deep end

If you have always thought that scuba-diving looked like a lot of fun, especially on holiday, but have never got around to trying it out, help is at hand. The British Sub-Aqua Club are offering free trial dives at up to 500 BSAC branches around the country from 11 to 17 September as part of Learn to Dive Week.

During the Try-Dive BSAC instructors will run through basic scuba theory and show you how to operate the aqualung and buoyancy equipment. Divers have to be over 14 years old, but children over eight can try snorkelling.

To find your nearest participating BSAC branch just call 0500 947 202. You don't have to be a BSAC member, but if you are bitten by the diving bug annual basic membership is £37 for adults or £12 for 14 to 18-year- olds and students - contact your local BSAC branch.

An Ocean Diver course costs from £200, after which you will be ready to explore reefs and wrecks around the world.

No nodding off with Noddy

Perfect for young children and long journeys is Noddy and the Birthday Party, a game produced by the BBC's multi-media department for the Game Boy Colour. The idea is to guide Noddy through 10 different adventures, collecting things from balloons to shells.

There is a gentle educational element: kids can play in French, German and Spanish as well as in English, and the game involves a little counting, as Noddy saves money to buy Big Ears a cake. More importantly, it should be absorbing for even the most fidgety four-year-old. Available from the usual stockists.

South Lakes Wild Animals Park

Curators at this unique zoo in Cumbria have striven to create environments that are as close to natural habitats as possible. The animals are gathered together by the continents they live on, and there are no cages, so the monkeys can climb and the lemurs can run free. The Australasian section boasts the country's largest collection of kangaroo species and the park is home to the Sumatran Tiger Trust, set up to protect the last few individuals of this species. Open 10am-6pm. Adults £6.50, children/OAPs £3.25, family £17. Call 01229 466806 or visit www.wildanimalpark.co.uk

fields.headline: Winning over the majority
fields.standfirst: A Catholic Assemblyman defied death threats to win a strongly loyalist seat - and he's sure it can be done again
fields.trailText: Danny O'Connor has only one place in his native Larne where he can buy a drink to celebrate the thirtieth birthday of the Social Democratic and Labour Party tomorrow. The party's first ever Assembly member for loyalist-dominated East Antrim will have to confine himself to the local Catholic parish hall if he wants to uncork a bottle and toast the SDLP's founding fathers.
fields.body:
Danny O'Connor has only one place in his native Larne where he can buy a drink to celebrate the thirtieth birthday of the Social Democratic and Labour Party tomorrow. The party's first ever Assembly member for loyalist-dominated East Antrim will have to confine himself to the local Catholic parish hall if he wants to uncork a bottle and toast the SDLP's founding fathers.

For Catholics in Larne, the port town which has witnessed an upsurge in sectarian attacks over the past fortnight, do not drink in the town at night for fear of being beaten up, or even killed, by loyalist gangs. To them, the area's pubs and clubs are no-go areas.

O'Connor himself has been at the sharp end of loyalist aggression since he was first elected to the Northern Ireland Assembly in 1998. His home has been attacked 12 times since the Good Friday Agreement was signed, and last week his brother's house was petrol bombed.

Yet this burly 35-year-old former security guard personifies the SDLP's best strategy to preserve its status as the principal nationalist party of Northern Ireland in face of a formidable threat from Sinn Fein.

His working-class roots challenge the stereotype of the SDLP simply being the party of the Catholic middles classes - teachers, solicitors and doctors. Elected to a constituency with an overwhelming Protestant majority, east of the river Bann, his success gives his party some hope that it can keep the IRA's political wing at bay. O'Connor has attracted the first preference votes of former Alliance Party voters and even second and third preference transfers from pro-Agreement Ulster Unionists - something Sinn Fein finds impossible to achieve outside the nationalist electorate.

The SDLP Assemblyman's office is a monument to the bigotry that blights Larne. The town has strong historical ties to hardline loyalism dating back to 1912, when the original Ulster Volunteer Force landed 30,000 rifles from the Clyde valley to arm people willing violently to resist Home Rule in Ireland. The windows of the office, above butchers' shop in Main Street, are bullet proof. There are scrapes and marks on the panes from the countless bricks, bottles and ball bearings fired at the SDLP base.

Inside last Friday afternoon O'Connor was counselling nervous Catholic families whose homes were petrol bombed last week during an orgy of sectarian intimidation across the town organised by the Ulster Defence Association.

Under siege from extreme loyalists, O'Connor takes comfort from the framed photograph on the wall of the American civil rights leader, Martin Luther King , one of his greatest heroes. His other hero is the SDLP leader, John Hume.

'There are two reasons why I joined the party seven years ago, he said. 'I used to work as a security guard at Shorts [aircraft factory] and I remember the day that loyalists shot up a minibus full of contract workers who were painting and decorating at the plant. These were guys I used to let into the factory in east Belfast every morning and say hello or good morning to. And then, when that gun attack happened, one of them was dead, wrapped in a blanket that barely covered him. The others were badly injured.

'I thought something should be done to stop this madness.'

The shooting happened in 1993, when Hume was talking to Sinn Fein's Gerry Adams in an attempt to persuade republicans to give up violence.

'John was coming under considerable pressure and criticism but I will never forget watching the relatives of the victims of the Greysteel massacre coming over to him at the funerals and telling him he had their full support to keep on talking. I remember Hume breaking down in tears and that's when I knew I had to join the party,' he said.

Like many SDLP representatives living in mainly loyalist areas, O'Connor paid the price for entering politics. Some of the party's early leaders were victims of both loyalist and republican intimidation. Austin Currie, now a Fine Gael TD in Dublin, suffered attacks from the UVF and the IRA. Loyalists bombed Seamus Mallon's home. Former leader Gerry Fitt had to force an IRA-inspired mob out of his house at gunpoint after they broke into his home threatening him and his family. As he waved his legally-held gun at the intruders, one of them shouted: 'Look, he's a coward, he's got a gun.' Worst of all Lord Fitt's friend Senator Paddy Wilson and his friend Irene Andrews were stabbed to death in a frenzied knife attack.

O'Connor accepted the risks of being a nationalist representative in a loyalist stronghold. 'The first cases I dealt with were Catholic constituents being burnt out of their homes. The people I represent are under attack and that means I have to stand firm and keep going.'

He blames the East Antrim UDA for orchestrating most of the violence directed against him, his family and his constituents. The RUC have told him he is on a loyalist death list. Yet he has founded the first branch of the SDLP in Larne and predicts that the party will elect more councillors to the local borough council next May.

West of the Bann, the party is fighting a rearguard struggle against a highly organised, disciplined and well-financed Sinn Fein. In Westminster constituencies such as West Tyrone, it is Sinn Fein rather than the SDLP which is seen as the main challenger to the sitting Unionist MPs. But east of the river dividing Northern Ireland, John Hume's party is clearly making inroads into the Alliance vote and gaining fresh support from the new Catholic middle-class emerging in areas that were once 100 per cent unionist.

Optimistically, O'Connor dismisses the prophets of doom who predict the demise of the SDLP and the further rise of Sinn Fein.

'The Agreement was pure SDLP politics in practice, compromise and common sense. They've been arguing for a settlement like this for 30 years long before Sinn Fein started to get into real politics. Unlike Sinn Fein I can reach out to others beyond nationalism, to people from Unionist and Alliance backgrounds that voted for the Agreement. All republican violence achieved over 25 years was to drive people further apart.'

webTitle: Kids' Escape: things to do this week

fields.headline: Make a big splash in the swimathons
fields.trailText:
A whale of a time
National Whale and Dolphin Awareness week beings on Saturday. Splash out in one of the organised swimathons around the country or organise your own event to raise money for these endangered cetaceans. To find out about the organised events or to get a sponsorship form call 01225 334511.
fields.body:
A whale of a time
National Whale and Dolphin Awareness week beings on Saturday. Splash out in one of the organised swimathons around the country or organise your own event to raise money for these endangered cetaceans. To find out about the organised events or to get a sponsorship form call 01225 334511.

Back to the future
The Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester is home until 28 August to FutureWorld, the BBC exhibition which lets you see some of the technology that makes programmes such as Walking with Dinosaurs possible. The museum is also hosting special events throughout the summer holidays, as well as hands-on exhibitions reflecting the region's heritage. Call 0161 832 1830 for a programme of events. Adults £5, concessions £3, under-18s free.

Kite fever
The skies above Bournemouth will be awash with colour today for the seventeenth annual Kite Festival at Hengistbury Head. Join in from 10.30am or just watch. Stalls will be selling every kind of kite and workshops will help novices fly for the first time. Bring Teddy and he could win you a certificate in the freefall parachute jump. Entrance is free. Call 0906 802 0234 (calls 50p a minute standard rate).

Citrus sprint
Before embarking on his 'Famous Voyage', rumour has it that a young Francis Drake fell in High Street, Totnes, Devon, while carrying a basket of oranges. This fruity fall is remembered on Tuesday at the Orange Races in the town centre. There are races for all ages and the winners will get cups and prizes. The disabled have their own event. Admission free. Call 01803 863714

Garlic galore
Count Dracula will be staying away from the Isle of Wight today as the Garlic Festival takes place at Newchurch, near Sandown. There will be a children's fun zone, spectacular arena events, a funfair and oodles of garlic both in a huge variety of dishes and as part of a display of locally grown produce. Open 10am-6pm, admission free. Call 01983 856411.

Snap happy
One of the pioneers of photography, William Henry Fox Talbot makes a posthumous appearance at the V&A museum from Tuesday until Friday. An actor will demonstrate some of his early experiments before focusing on solar photography, which visitors can try for themselves. There are two sessions, at noon and 3pm, which last two hours. Meet in the Pirelli Gardens (Sculpture and Architecture Gallery if bad weather). Adults £5, OAPs £3, under 18s and concessions free. Call 020 7942 2000.

Carnival time
Next Sunday is Kids' Day at the thirty-sixth annual Notting Hill Carnival. 'Every spectator is a participant' is the motto of the UK's largest multicultural festival so get dressed up and join in. The event starts at around midday and the musicians, food and sound systems finish about 7pm.

Get in a spin
Learn how fleece becomes fabric at one of the Woolly Workshops held by the Museum of the Welsh Woollen Industry in Llandysul, Ceredigion. The workshops run from Tuesday until Thursday and visitors will learn about about carding, spinning and weaving. 10am-1pm and 2-5pm. Adults £2.60, concessions £1.60, under 18s/OAPs/unemployed free. Call 01559 370929.

Fair games
Ireland's oldest traditional market, the Oul' Lammas Fair, celebrates its 400th anniversary this year. The market takes place in picturesque Ballycastle on the Antrim coast on 28-29 August with Nickelodean paying a visit on the Tuesday on their Red Hot Lobster Tour. Both days will feature games, fairground rides and livestock trading. Call 08701 555250.

Hot-rodding
For hot-rod enthusiasts, 'See you at the Nats' is an invitation to Europe's largest gathering of custom cars. The International Custom Car Show is held at the Essex County Showground, Great Leighs from Friday until 28 August and will feature a procession through Braintree. Open 9am-5.30pm. Call 07808 427305.

webTitle: Nepal: Akin Ojumu goes trekking in the Himalayas

fields.headline: Up where we  belong...
fields.standfirst: Breakfast at six, dinner at six, pubs shut at 10.  Akin Ojumu  lives the spiritual high life on a mountain trek amid the most stunning scenery on earth, that serves as a backdrop to a new film, Himalaya
fields.trailText: No pain, no gain could be the Nepalese national motto. Especially in the Himalayas. At roughly 4,000m above sea-level you're confronted by a glorious trinity of mountain, valley and brilliant blue sky. It's enough to take your breath away. But the exertion of getting there has probably done that already. Of course, the pay-off is striking.
fields.body:
No pain, no gain could be the Nepalese national motto. Especially in the Himalayas. At roughly 4,000m above sea-level you're confronted by a glorious trinity of mountain, valley and brilliant blue sky. It's enough to take your breath away. But the exertion of getting there has probably done that already. Of course, the pay-off is striking.

It's easy to forget the views that persuade thousands of travellers to test their limbs and resolve each year are commonplace to the inhabitants of the mountain kingdom. As you trek through the hills, you constantly encounter nonplussed locals. This extraordinary locale has provided the inspiration for a new film reminiscent in scale and content of a John Ford western. Set in the Dolpo region of the north-western Himalayas, Himalaya is the tale of an epic journey from a village deep in the Nepalese Himalayas down to the lush valleys. The yak caravan undertakes this hazardous journey in order to swap their salt reserves for precious grain. It's a relentless trek blessed, literally, by the gods.

The Dolpo region is one of the most isolated and highest areas of the Himalayas, fiercely protected by natural barriers, almost a hidden country. If you want to experience the trekking life without that kind of struggle, best head towards more hospitable hills.

The most popular trek for keen walkers is the Annapurna circuit across the north Himalayan range, which takes three weeks to cross, including a 5,416m pass. For a gentler introduction, I embarked on the Jomson trek, basically the last third of Annapurna circuit. Tourism accounts for 16 per cent of Nepal's GDP, but up in the hills it's often the main source of income. The region is traditionally populated with tenant and subsistence farmers. Post-war mountaineers spoke of the area's beauty and since the Sixties it has become a hot destination for adventurous sun seekers.

Trekking is a Nepalese way of life; there are few reliable roads at altitude so you will see plenty of villagers along the way. Modern technology has left the region largely alone. The electricity supply is solar powered. The main signs of Western influence are the number of Nepalese men clad in brands such as Nike, Reebok and Adidas. Most impressive are the Herculean feats of those carrying heavy loads, ranging from man-sized bundles to 12ft slabs of building timber. I had been warned that the monsoon period, from June to September, brings slippery slopes and wet socks. So I came prepared, over-prepared. I'd bought my boots and jacket in Kathmandu for a third of the British price. From there I flew to the staging town of Pokhara, home to Nepal's equivalent of the hippie trail. Restaurants have names such as Chill Out and Ganga and the nightlife is vibrant. But I stepped out of the light aircraft into blazing sunshine.

'It's just like the desert,' says my personal guide Roshan. Born in neighbouring Bhutan, Roshan went to school in Kathmandu and stayed. During the off-season he has an enforced four-month break without pay so looks forward to October. It obviously hasn't rained here for some time and, according to Roshan, it seldom does. Ironically, flying to Jomson from Pokhara I had seen rows of green, fertile hills covered in trees, while the tiers of paddy fields made much of the landscape look strangely wrinkled.

From a clear day on the higher levels of the Jomson trail you can see Everest. The trail, which from October will be teeming, was quiet. During the trip I saw few other travellers. When the plane arrived, porters and guides lined up to greet their prospective employers. The runway marks the end of the long street which is the village's sole thoroughfare. Apart from the activity around the runway, Jomson (2,713m) looked like a Mexican border town; gift shops and teahouses - essentially backpacking hostels - lined the rugged road. Mountain people are stoic and philosophical. When my 30-minute flight was delayed by mist over Jomson for two and a half hours, there were no complaints in the departure lounge. As we waited on the runway to board the return flight, Roshan calmly told me that Nepalese light aircraft have an unenviable safety record. Indeed he fortuitously missed a plane last year, which was later involved in a fatal crash.

The trekking day begins around 6am and ends around 4pm. We arrived at lunch time, too late to do a proper day's walking. Roshan hired a porter and I watched guiltily as he hoisted my holdall on to his shoulder. We headed towards Marpha, a tiny village famous for apples. The views were breathtaking from the valley floor; there was a harsh beauty to the arid landscape beneath the impressive cloudless sky. Our first journey was punctuated by my camera stops.

I realised later that the two-hour trek to Marpha has been a relative stroll, consisting of a few short descents and ascents, but essentially flat. The main attraction at Marpha (2,665m) is the apple brandy distillery. It's a favourite destination for thirsty trekkers who are allowed to taste the product during guided tours. This is hard stuff, 75 per cent proof, and it tastes like it should be on a paintbrush rather than my tongue. Still, I bought a couple of bottles for 50 rupees each (about 50p). Emboldened by the earlier walk, I persuaded Roshan to lead me up the hill to large white-and-brown dyed rock surrounded by multi-coloured flags. It is the sign that Buddhists live here. It was a short, arduous trek for a humble beginner. Roshan strode ahead and I scrambled up in his wake. At the top I breathlessly flopped on to a large rock. He looked perturbed. This did not bode well for the next few days.

The Nepalese rise early. A mouthful of breakfast at six; a large lunch around 10; an evening meal around six. In the capital Kathmandu, the handful of bars shut at 10pm. This took some getting used to. But the food on the trail did not. It is indicative of how the trekking experience has been overly sensitive towards Western tastes. Even the humblest backpacker hotel boasts a selection of Chinese, American, Indian, Mexican and Italian dishes.The local lentil and rice staple, dal bhat tarakari, is notoriously hard to find. Apple pie, however, is in abundance.

Today we headed back towards Jomson on the way to Kagbani (2,810m). The monsoon rains had swollen the river Kagbani to cover the valley floor, so we had to wade across in bare feet. Although Nepal is an overwhelmingly Hindu country, the mountain people are mostly Buddhist. Every village contains a temple, monastery or religious statue. It's tempting to find religious significance even in the mundane. The following day on the way to Muktinath (3,710m), the next, steep stage of the trail, I was taken by a curious circular arrangement of stones. The letter H appeared to have been spelt out in the middle. 'What's that?' I asked. 'It's for the helicopter landing,' Roshan said drily.

At the end of my trekking stint, I was blister-free and only slightly stiff. Still, it was a relief to return to the comforts of my hotel room at Kathmandu's Royal Singi Hotel. Kathmandu is a bustling city whose 500,000 residents make their presence felt. A drive around the city reveals unsettling levels of poverty and sanitation. Most travellers end up sooner or later in Thamel, a sprawling bazaar of narrow streets crammed with shops. While shopping, bargaining is obligatory. Head to the Durbar Square for a look at the temples and palaces.

Despite the undoubted allure of Kathmandu, the charm of Nepal lies in the hills. The scenery in the Himalayas, which include eight of the world's 10 highest mountains, is probably unrivalled anywhere. But perhaps the real selling point is the chance to embark on a spiritual break. This must be what they call the high life.

Fact file

Akin Ojumu's itinerary was specially created by Exodus (020 8772 3821) but much of the route is covered in a 24-day 'Annapurna Circuit' tour that costs from £1,298. A 17-day tour of Jomson and the Kau Gandaki costs from £1,198. Exodus has 20 itineraries to Nepal with prices from £795. See www.exodus.co.uk
